Pay attention to the contrast between David's suffering and the enemies' rejoicing (v.10-11)
The phrase 'my soul is with you' (v.10) shows David's trust in God

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David) is pleading with God, WHAT (to contend against enemies who seek his life), WHERE (in the midst of worshiping Israel), and WHY (because enemies are repaying evil for good and causing David to suffer).
tips: David is pleading for God to contend against his enemies who seek his life (v.1)
Enemies repaid him evil for good and rejoiced at his stumbling (v.12)
David's soul is with God despite the suffering (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Let those who seek my life be put to shame' (v.11), 'My soul is with you' (v.10), or 'How long will God look on?' (v.12).
tips: The phrase 'let those who seek my life be put to shame' (v.11) shows David's confidence in God's justice
The line 'how long will God look on?' (v.12) is a plea for immediate divine intervention
The contrast in v.10 between David's sackcloth and the enemies' rejoicing highlights the injustice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's response to enemies of the righteous?
tips: David emphasizes that God delights in the welfare of His servant (v.20)
The passage calls for God to vindicate the righteous and crush the enemies of justice
This plea is rooted in David's experience of being persecuted by enemies who repaid him evil for good

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'let those who seek my life be put to shame' (v.11) - how does this fit with the context of David being in danger? The use of 'sackcloth' (v.10) - what does it symbolize? The contrast between 'evil repaid for good' and God's ultimate justice?
tips: The phrase 'sackcloth' (v.10) symbolizes mourning and humility, showing David's distress
The phrase 'how long will God look on?' (v.12) implies a sense of urgency for God's intervention in the face of prolonged suffering
The term 'vindication' (v.20) refers to God's final judgment on the wicked and restoration of the righteous

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the plea for divine justice in your life when you feel like God is delaying justice for the wrongs done to you?
tips: Consider an enemy who has repaid you evil for good (v.12) and pray for God's intervention
Practice the discipline of 'sackcloth' by mourning the wrongs done to you and seeking God's strength
Ask God to 'let those who seek your life be put to shame' (v.11) in your life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God that He delights in the welfare of His servant (v.20). Ask for strength to endure enemies who seek your life and for God to put them to shame.
tips: Thank God for His justice in your life
Pray for courage to trust God when enemies are active against you
Ask God to let the wicked who seek your life be put to shame (v.11)

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the contrast between verses 1-3 (wickedness) and verses 4-8 (God's love)
Pay attention to the repetition of 'His' in the description of God's love
The phrase 'in His light we see light' (verse 8) is a powerful closing

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the wicked and God) does WHAT (wickedness and God's steadfast love) WHERE (in the hearts of the wicked and in God's presence) and WHY (to contrast the wickedness with God's loving character and provide hope).
tips: Include the wicked's transgression and lack of fear of God (verses 1-3)
Note God's steadfast love that extends to heavens and His faithfulness to clouds (verses 4-5)
Mention the saving of man and beast and the feast imagery (verses 6-7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the wicked (verses 1-3), God's righteousness like mountains (verse 5), or the light imagery (verse 8)?
tips: The phrase 'in His light we see light' (verse 8) is a metaphor for spiritual clarity and the presence of God
The stark contrast between the wicked's deceit (verses 1-3) and God's saving power (verses 4-8) is powerful
The image of God's love being 'precious' (verse 8) and the refuge under His wings (verse 7) speaks to deep security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and the response to wickedness?
tips: David contrasts the wickedness of the people with God's unwavering love and faithfulness
The main point is that despite the presence of wickedness, God's steadfast love provides refuge and abundance
This psalm is a call to trust God in the midst of a hostile world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of wickedness, the imagery of God's love, and the connection to Christ?
tips: The phrase 'transgression speaks to the wicked deep in their hearts' (verse 1) means that sin is internal and pervasive
The imagery of 'righteousness like mighty mountains' (verse 5) is a poetic device to show stability and strength
The phrase 'in His light we see light' (verse 8) is a metaphor for the clarity of God's presence, which is a promise of hope

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's steadfast love and refuge to your life this week?
tips: When you feel overwhelmed by the wickedness in the world, remember that God's love covers you and you can take refuge in Him
Pray for the courage to trust God's provision in your current situation
Offer a specific act of worship or service that reflects the feast at God's house (e.g., sharing a meal with others)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His steadfast love and ask for the courage to take refuge in Him.
tips: Thank God for His steadfast love that covers you even when you are in the midst of wickedness
Ask for the strength to trust His provision in your current challenges
Pray for others to experience the feast and light of God's presence

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 38:1-37 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and repeated phrases.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'my iniquities' (v. 2, 4) showing deep guilt
Pay attention to the physical suffering descriptions: 'wounds fester', 'loins filled with burning' (v. 7, 8)
The plea for help: 'Make haste to help me, O Lord, my salvation' (v. 22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is suffering, WHAT is happening to them, WHERE they are, and WHY they are praying.
tips: David's internal state of being overwhelmed by sin and divine punishment
His physical and spiritual wounds from God's wrath
The plea for God's help and deliverance

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of physical suffering (v. 7), the emotional plea (v. 22), or the contrast with God's faithfulness (v. 23)?
tips: The physical description: 'wounds fester from foolishness' (v. 7) shows the futility of human wisdom in suffering
The emotional plea: 'Make haste to help me, O Lord, my salvation' (v. 22) is a cry for immediate divine intervention
The contrast: 'I have become a fool, but you are the Lord' (v. 23) highlights the humility in suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's response to suffering and sin?
tips: David is showing that even in the deepest suffering, God is the refuge
The passage emphasizes that God's anger is a consequence of sin, but He remains faithful to the covenant
This psalm prefigures Christ as the one who bears the wrath of God for sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The physical suffering in relation to sin? Why God's anger? The role of friends?
tips: The phrase 'wounds fester from foolishness' (v. 7) might be interpreted as a result of sin, but in ancient Hebrew, 'foolishness' (chatah) refers to sin
The term 'divine hand presses down' (v. 4) describes God's active wrath, but in the context of a covenant relationship, it's a consequence of sin
The abandonment by friends (v. 17) is a common experience in suffering, but David's trust in God is the key

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'prayer in severe suffering' this week? Consider: when your physical or spiritual wounds are festered, what does David's cry for help teach you?
tips: When you feel overwhelmed by sin or suffering, pray like David: 'Make haste to help me, O Lord, my salvation'
Surrender your 'wounds' to God and trust in His provision
Practice the humility that David shows: 'I have become a fool, but you are the Lord'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is your refuge in the midst of suffering. Ask for His deliverance and faithfulness.
tips: Thank God that He is your refuge and strength in the midst of suffering
Pray for the courage to trust Him when your wounds fester
Ask God to help you become a fool in the sense of humility, so you can rely on Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 40:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between David in the pit and God's deliverance.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord' (v. 1, 3, 6, 8, 9, 12)
Pay attention to the metaphor of being drawn from the pit and set on a rock (v. 3)
The phrase 'your law is within my heart' (v. 9) is a key declaration of obedience

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David) is being delivered, WHAT God does (draws him from the pit and sets him on a rock), WHERE and WHEN it happens (in the context of worship), and WHY David waits (for God's deliverance).
tips: Include the three key events: being in the pit (v. 1), being drawn out (v. 3), and the new song (v. 5)
Note that David is poor and needy but the Lord thinks of him (v. 12)
David proclaims good news in the congregation (v. 10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's waiting in the pit (v. 1), God setting his feet on a rock (v. 3), or 'your law is within my heart' (v. 9)?
tips: The image of being drawn from the pit and set on a rock (v. 3) is a powerful metaphor for deliverance from deep trouble
The declaration 'your law is within my heart' (v. 9) shows complete obedience and internal transformation
The call to rejoice for those who seek God (v. 11) is a joyful response to deliverance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's faithfulness in delivering the needy?
tips: David emphasizes that God is the deliverer who acts for the needy (v. 12)
True worship is about obedience and trust, not sacrifice (v. 8, 9)
This passage is a declaration of God's covenant faithfulness to His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'pit' (v. 1) - is it literal or metaphorical? The 'rock' (v. 3) - what does it represent? The phrase 'your law is within my heart' (v. 9) - how does this relate to obedience?
tips: The 'pit' (Hebrew: 'mavet') can mean a deep hole, a situation of distress, or even death
The 'rock' (Hebrew: 'mishpah') might represent stability and the foundation of God's promises
The phrase 'your law is within my heart' (v. 9) is a common expression in the Psalms for complete internal obedience

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: David proclaims good news in the congregation (v. 10). What specific action can you take this week to share the good news of God's deliverance with someone?
tips: Think of a person who is in a difficult situation and might need hope
Practice being a 'proclaimer' of God's deliverance, just as David did
Start with a small act of sharing hope and the truth that God is with you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for delivering you from your pits and set your feet on the rock of His promises. Ask for the heart to have His law within you.
tips: Thank God for delivering you from your pits (v. 12)
Ask for the courage to set your feet on the rock of God's promises (v. 3)
Pray for the heart to have God's law within you (v. 9) and to proclaim His good news

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 41:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the emotional contrast between the betrayal and God's provision.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'blessed' in verse 1 and 13
Pay attention to the phrase 'he who eats my bread' (v4) and the enemy's malice
The phrase 'the Lord delivers him' (v1) is a key promise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is blessed, WHAT God does, WHERE this blessing is found, and WHY the psalmist is confident.
tips: Include the betrayal by a close friend (v4)
Note that the psalmist is in trouble but God is his protector (v1, v5)
The enemy's hope that he dies is contrasted with God's deliverance (v2-3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blessing for the poor (v1), the betrayal by a close friend (v4), or God's eternal provision (v8-13)?
tips: The phrase 'blessed is the one who considers the poor' (v1) shows the psalmist's humility and care for the weak
The betrayal by a friend who shared bread (v4) is a powerful image of how even allies can turn against you
The assurance that God sets the psalmist in His presence forever (v8) is a profound promise of eternal security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's care for the weak?
tips: This psalm emphasizes that God's blessing is found in those who care for the poor, even in the face of betrayal
It reassures the community that God's faithfulness triumphs over the enemy's schemes
The psalmist's confidence comes from knowing God's eternal covenant with him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the friend who betrays (v4), the meaning of 'the Lord delivers' (v1), or the concept of God's eternal provision (v8-13)?
tips: The phrase 'he who eats my bread' (v4) refers to a close friend in the context of sharing meals, which was a sign of deep friendship in ancient Israel
In Hebrew, 'delivers' (yadah) implies rescue from immediate danger, not a general blessing
The promise of 'eternal blessing' (v13) is a reference to God's covenant with David, which the psalmist believes will last forever

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice caring for the weak this week, as the psalmist did?
tips: Identify one person in your life who is in need and offer practical help
Reflect on a time when you felt betrayed by a friend and how God's promise of deliverance reassured you
Commit to being a 'friend who shares bread' (v4) by supporting others in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His care for the weak and ask for the courage to be a blessing to others.
tips: Thank God for protecting you in the midst of betrayal
Ask for the strength to be a friend who shares bread with the poor
Pray that God's deliverance from enemies will come to you when you are in trouble

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 43:1-4 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'send your light and truth', 'let them lead me', and 'let them bring me to your holy hill and your dwelling'.
tips: Note the repetition of 'send' and 'let them' to emphasize God's active role
Pay attention to the contrast between the psalmist's current state (cast down) and the hope of going to God's altar with joy

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the psalmist is addressing, WHAT God is called to do, WHERE this leads, and WHY the psalmist needs this guidance.
tips: The psalmist is David addressing God
God is called to send light and truth that guide and bring the psalmist to His holy place
The purpose is vindication from ungodly enemies and hope in God's presence

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the request for light and truth (v.1), the promise of being brought to God's dwelling (v.1), or the joyful declaration of going to the altar (v.2).
tips: The phrase 'send your light and truth' is a call for God to be the active guide in a time of darkness
The imagery of being led to 'your holy hill and dwelling' connects to the temple in Jerusalem, a place of God's presence
The joyful declaration 'I will go to your altar' shows that the psalmist's hope in God leads to praise

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's role in providing light and truth for their journey and vindication?
tips: David emphasizes that God's light and truth are the means by which Israel can be vindicated and find their place in God's presence
This reflects God as the ultimate refuge and guide for the faithful, especially when facing enemies
The psalm ties into the theme of hope that conquers despair, as seen in the refrain 'Why are you cast down? Hope in God!'

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'holy hill', the role of 'them' in 'let them lead me', and the phrase 'why are you cast down' in the context of the psalm.
tips: 'Holy hill' (Hebrew: 'seir') refers to the mountain of God, the place of worship in ancient Israel (e.g., Jerusalem's Mount Zion)
'Them' in 'let them lead me' refers to the light and truth that God sends, which are active guides
'Cast down' (Hebrew: 'kavod') describes a state of being humbled or discouraged, often due to the presence of enemies

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's light and truth guiding you to His presence this week? Identify one area where you need God's guidance and ask Him to lead you to His dwelling.
tips: Choose a specific decision or situation where you feel lost and ask God for His light and truth
Practice stepping into God's presence by going to a place of worship or quiet time
Remember that God's light and truth are active in your life to guide you away from enemies and toward His dwelling

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His light and truth that guide us, and ask for hope in Him when we feel cast down.
tips: Thank God for sending His light and truth to guide your journey
Ask God to help you overcome feelings of being cast down by enemies
Pray for others who are struggling with despair and hope in God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 44:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the repeated questioning about God's absence (verses 1-4, 7) and the desperate plea for help (verses 7-8).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'why do you hide your face?' (verse 4 and 7) showing the deep sense of abandonment
Listen for the imagery of being 'sheep to be slaughtered' (verse 6) as a metaphor for vulnerability in suffering

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Identify the main themes of the passage: the current suffering of the nation and the plea for God's redemption.
tips: Note how the psalmist contrasts the past faithfulness of God (driving out nations) with the current state of rejection
Remember that the people have not turned to other gods but are still calling on God

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Choose 2-3 specific phrases or images from the passage that most resonate with your current situation.
tips: The phrase 'we are killed all day long' (verse 5) illustrates the constant, grinding suffering of the people
The image of being 'sheep to be slaughtered' (verse 6) is a powerful metaphor for feeling vulnerable and targeted by enemies
The call to action 'Rise up; redeem us for your steadfast love!' (verse 8) shows the hope in God's redemption

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to the nation of Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage is a plea for God to remember His covenant and act in their favor when they are in distress
It emphasizes that even in the midst of national failure, the people of God are called to hold fast to the covenant and trust in God's redemption

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 elements in the passage that might be confusing to modern readers.
tips: The phrase 'for your sake we are killed all day long' (verse 5) - in Hebrew, this phrase might mean 'because of your (God's) name', but in context, it's the people suffering due to God's apparent abse
The concept of God's absence is not permanent abandonment but a temporary state of being tested
The image of being 'sheep to be slaughtered' is a metaphor for being vulnerable to enemies, which may not be the primary context in ancient Near Eastern warfare

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'innocent suffering' to your life when you feel God is absent?
tips: Write down one time when you felt God seemed absent and how you can remember His past faithfulness
Pray for God to wake you up and redeem you when you feel abandoned

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God to wake up and redeem you when you feel abandoned.
tips: Thank God for His steadfast love that remains even when we feel abandoned
Ask God to wake us up and redeem us for His love
Pray that we don't forget God's covenant and trust in His redemption

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 45:1-8 aloud, focusing on the descriptions of the king's beauty and the bride's devotion.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the king' and 'the bride' in verses 2-8
Pay attention to the phrase 'your throne, O God, is forever' in verse 6
Emphasize the contrast between the king's power and the bride's devotion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the king and the bride), WHAT (the king's qualities and the bride's response), WHERE (in the kingdom of God), and WHY (to establish the eternal kingdom of the king).
tips: The king is described as fairer than the sons of men (v.2)
The bride is called to forsake her people and father's house (v.5)
The king's throne is eternal (v.6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the king's beauty (v.2), the call to gird your sword (v.3), or the eternal throne (v.6)?
tips: The phrase 'the king is fairer than the sons of men' (v.2) highlights the king's exceptional beauty and righteousness
The command 'gird your sword, mighty one' (v.3) shows the king's readiness for battle and victory
The statement 'your throne, O God, is forever' (v.6) is a powerful declaration of eternal rule

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the king who will rule forever?
tips: David is proclaiming the king (Messiah) who is righteous and will rule eternally
The bride (the Church) is called to forsake worldly ties and be devoted to the king
This passage foreshadows Christ as the eternal king and the Church as His bride

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of the queen in Ophir? Why the king is called 'the mighty one'? The eternal throne?
tips: Ophir (a land of gold) symbolizes the rich heritage of the Church, not a physical queen
The term 'mighty one' refers to the king's strength and authority, not a military force
The eternal throne (v.6) points to Christ's eternal rule, which is a theological concept that may be hard to grasp

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of the bride's devotion to your life this week?
tips: Forsake worldly distractions by focusing on the king's beauty (Christ)
Pray for courage to become the bride who forgets her people and father's house (v.5)
Surrender your possessions and ambitions to the king's rule

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the king who desires your beauty and ask for the strength to forsake the world.
tips: Thank God for the king (Christ) who is fairer than the sons of men
Pray for the courage to become the bride of Christ and forget worldly things
Ask God to help you live in devotion to the king's eternal rule

chapters.chapterTitle: God Is Our Refuge and Strength

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 46:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'God is' and the declarative tone of confidence.
tips: Notice the phrase 'God is our refuge' appears twice in the verse range (v.1 and v.7)
Pay attention to the contrast between chaos (v.3-5) and divine stability (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (God and Israel), WHAT (God as refuge and strength), WHERE (the city of God), and WHY (to provide security during chaos).
tips: God's presence as unshakable refuge in the midst of natural disasters
The city of God (Israel) remains secure because God dwells within it

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast of chaos (v.3-5), the river of life (v.6), or God's presence (v.7).
tips: The image of 'earth gives way, mountains fall into the sea' (v.3-5) vividly illustrates chaos that God can overcome
The statement 'God is in her midst; she shall not be moved' (v.7) provides the ultimate assurance of security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God being their refuge and strength?
tips: To reassure Israel that God's presence provides unshakable security even when the world is in turmoil
This passage was likely written during times of external threats to encourage trust in God's protection

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the city of God (v.6), the phrase 'the earth melts' (v.9), or God as fortress (v.10)?
tips: The 'city of God' refers to Jerusalem as the spiritual center of worship, not a physical city
'The earth melts' is a metaphor for God's power destroying natural order, not a literal earthquake
The 'fortress' is God's protective presence, not a physical structure

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of being still and knowing God as your refuge. What situation requires you to trust God's strength this week?
tips: Identify a current stressor (e.g., job insecurity, family conflict) and pray for God's peace
Practice 'being still' for 5 minutes daily to hear God's voice in chaos

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for being your refuge and strength. Ask for courage to trust Him in the chaos of your life.
tips: Thank God that 'God is in her midst; she shall not be moved'
Ask for the strength to remain calm when the world feels unstable

chapters.chapterTitle: God Is King of All the Earth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 47:1-9 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'God' and the call to clap and shout.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'God' (appears 4 times in the chapter)
Pay attention to the call to 'clap your hands' (v.1) and 'shout' (v.1) which creates a joyful, communal tone
The phrase 'the Lord Most High' (v.1) emphasizes God's universal sovereignty

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the people of Israel and nations) does WHAT (praise God), WHERE (the earth), and WHY (because God is the universal king).
tips: Include the key event: God's subduing of peoples and choosing Israel's heritage (v.3)
Note the ascension of God with a shout and trumpet (v.4) as a sign of triumph
The gathering of princes from nations as Abraham's people (v.7) shows God's inclusion of all nations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to clap and shout (v.1), God's ascension (v.4), or the gathering of princes (v.7)?
tips: The phrase 'God has gone up with a shout, the Lord with the sound of trumpet' (v.4) is vivid and shows God's active, triumphant entry into the world
The image of 'princes of the peoples gather as the people of the God of Abraham' (v.7) is powerful because it shows Gentiles being included in God's people through faith
The repetition of 'God' (v.1, v.2, v.5, v.8) emphasizes God's universal kingship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David was calling Israel to recognize God's universal kingship, not just their local rulership
The passage is a response to the fact that God had already conquered the nations and chosen Israel as His special people
This psalm also points to the future inclusion of Gentiles through faith, as the 'princes of the peoples' gather as Abraham's people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of God 'going up' with a shout, the meaning of 'princes of the peoples', or the idea of God as king over all nations?
tips: 'God has gone up' (v.4) is a poetic expression for God's ascension to a higher place of authority, not a physical movement
The 'princes of the peoples' (v.7) refers to the leaders of nations, which in the context of the time were the powerful kings and rulers
The idea of God being king over all nations (v.2) might be challenging because it seems to contradict the covenant with Israel alone, but the passage shows God's sovereignty extends to all nations

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of joyful praise and God's universal kingship. What can you do this week to praise God as the king of all the earth?
tips: Choose one specific way to praise God this week: like singing a song of praise or clapping to the rhythm of a worship song
Think about how you can share the joy of God's kingship with others in your community
Consider the practical step of thanking God for His provision in your life, especially in the midst of challenges

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about God being the king of all the earth and the joyful response of the nations.
tips: Thank God that He is the king of all the earth and has already conquered the nations
Pray for the courage to praise God joyfully in difficult circumstances
Ask God to help you see the nations as part of His kingdom and to share His joy with others

chapters.chapterTitle: The City of the Great King

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 48:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'great is the Lord', 'beautiful in elevation', and 'kings assembled against her' in verses 4-5.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'great' (v1) and 'joy' (v2) in the description of Zion
Pay attention to the shift from description to the enemy's defeat in verses 4-5
The phrase 'let Mount Zion be glad' (v5) has an active call to joy

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT God does, WHERE this is (Zion), WHY (to establish God's presence as refuge), and HOW (through the city's fortifications and God's judgments).
tips: Include the description of Zion's beauty and elevation (v2)
Note the historical context of enemies being routed (v4)
Highlight the call for generational testimony (v7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of Zion's beauty (v2), the enemy's defeat (v4), or the generational testimony (v7)?
tips: 'Beautiful in elevation, the joy of all the earth' (v2) captures the divine excellence of Zion
'Kings assembled against her but fled in terror' (v4) shows God's power over enemies
'Walk about Zion, count her towers...' (v6) invites active engagement with God's protection

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's presence and protection through this passage?
tips: David emphasizes that God is the fortress of Zion (v3) and the source of ultimate security
This passage reassures Israel that God's presence is their refuge and that their God is sovereign over all enemies
The focus on generational testimony (v7) shows that God's people are to pass on the truth of His faithfulness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of Zion as 'the city of our God' (v1), the enemy's defeat (v4), and the generational aspect (v7)?
tips: 'City of our God' in Hebrew refers to the holy mountain (Zion) as God's dwelling place, not a physical city
The phrase 'kings assembled against her' (v4) implies a historical context of threats that God overcame
The generational testimony (v7) requires understanding that the city of God is both physical and spiritual

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you walk about your spiritual 'Zion' (your place of worship and community) this week to count the towers of God's protection?
tips: Identify one area where you feel God's protection (e.g., your church community, your faith) and 'count' it by reflecting on God's presence
Pray for courage to face challenges as a fortress of God's presence
Share the testimony of God's presence with one person this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His fortress, ask for the courage to be a place of joy and refuge for others.
tips: Thank God that He is the fortress for His people (Psalm 48:3)
Pray for the strength to face challenges as a fortress of God's presence
Ask God to help you be a place of joy and refuge for others, as Zion is for Israel

chapters.chapterTitle: The Folly of Trusting in Wealth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 49:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the rich and the poor in verses 1-2 and the hope in God's redemption in verses 15-18.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the fool' (v. 1, 6, 14) and the contrast with the wise
Pay attention to the emotional tone of despair in verses 1-6 and hope in verses 15-18
The phrase 'ruthless' (v. 14) and 'ransom' (v. 15) are key

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is speaking, WHAT is being said about wealth and death, WHERE this occurs (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY the speaker is writing (to challenge the trust in wealth).
tips: Include the contrast between the rich and the poor (v. 1-2, 6)
Note the universal message to all peoples (v. 1)
The death of the rich and the poor both leaving wealth to others (v. 8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about wealth (v. 1-2), the futility of wealth (v. 6), or God's redemption (v. 15-18)?
tips: The phrase 'the rich man is like the dead' (v. 14) is powerful because it shows the ultimate futility of wealth
The contrast in v. 15-18: 'God will ransom my soul from Sheol' shows hope beyond death
The phrase 'fear not when a man becomes rich' (v. 12) challenges the reader to reconsider their security

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the folly of trusting in wealth?
tips: The purpose was to challenge the Israelites (and all people) who trusted in wealth to see that death is the great equalizer and that true security comes from God, not possessions
This passage foreshadows the Christian doctrine that Christ paid the ransom for our souls from Sheol (death)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of Sheol, the meaning of 'ransom', and the contrast between the rich and the poor?
tips: Sheol is the Hebrew word for the grave or underworld, not hell (a later concept) – so it's the place of the dead
Ransom in Hebrew (nachal) means to pay a price for someone's freedom; here it's the idea that no one can pay for another's soul
The passage uses the wealthy as an example of those who are 'fools' because they trust in wealth that will not last

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'Death the great equalizer' – what can you do this week to avoid trusting in wealth and instead seek God's redemption?
tips: Reflect on a time when you felt secure in your wealth or status and how it might have been temporary
Pray for the courage to let go of possessions that are temporary and trust God's provision
Make a list of 3 things that are truly valuable to you and pray that God will use them for His glory

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the true security, not wealth. Ask for the wisdom to see the folly of wealth and trust in Him.
tips: Thank God for the promise that He ransoms souls from Sheol (v. 15)
Pray for the strength to not fear death and to trust in Christ's redemption
Ask God to help you see the temporary nature of wealth and the eternal value of His kingdom

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 50:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between God's sovereignty (verses 1-2) and the call for true worship (verses 6-15).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I have seen' (v.2) and the contrast in the opening
Pay attention to the emotional shift from God's majesty to the warning to the wicked (v.16)
The phrase 'sacrifice' appears 4 times (v.3, 6, 10, 15) but the emphasis shifts to thanksgiving

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (judges and calls for true worship), WHERE (Zion and the earth), and WHY (to correct false worship and promote moral integrity).
tips: Include God's summons from Zion (v.1) and the earth (v.2)
Note the contrast between ritual sacrifices and true worship (v.6-7)
Highlight the warning to the wicked who recite statutes but hate discipline (v.16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's declaration in verse 2, the call for thanksgiving in verse 6, or the warning to the wicked in verse 16?
tips: The phrase 'I have seen' in verse 2 shows God's omniscience and the contrast with human actions
The command 'offer thanksgiving' (v.6) is a direct call to action that transcends ritual
The warning in verse 16: 'you recite my statutes but hate discipline' is a sharp critique of hypocritical worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage emphasizes that God desires a relationship based on moral integrity, not ritualistic offerings (v.6-7)
It warns that false worship (without obedience) will be torn apart (v.16-17)
The main point is that true worship is thankful obedience and moral uprightness, which God will show salvation for

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of God judging without sacrifice, the meaning of 'sacrifice' in this context, and the warning to the wicked?
tips: In ancient Israel, sacrifices were central to worship; here God says He doesn't need them because He owns all cattle (v.3) — this challenges the idea of ritual as the sole path to God
'Hate discipline' (v.16) refers to rejecting God's corrective teachings, not just moral failure
The phrase 'tear you apart' (v.16) is a strong warning that God will remove the wicked from His presence

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'true sacrifice is thanksgiving' this week?
tips: Consider an area where you've been focused on external rituals (like religious activities) but not internal thankfulness
Pray for the courage to offer thanksgiving in your daily life, even when it's difficult
This week, write down one thing you can thank God for that you might have overlooked

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's judgment on false worship and the call for true thanksgiving.
tips: Thank God that He values your heart more than ritual
Ask for the strength to live with moral integrity, avoiding the company of the wicked
Pray for God's deliverance when you face trouble (as promised in v.23)

chapters.chapterTitle: Create in Me a Clean Heart

tips: Include the context of David's sin with Bathsheba (implied in the psalm)
Note that David's confession is for his own cleansing, not for the nation of Israel
David's plea is for God to create a new heart (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Create in me a clean heart' (v.10), 'Purge me with hyssop; wash me whiter than snow' (v.7), or 'The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit' (v.17)?
tips: 'Create in me a clean heart' is the core of the psalm and speaks to the need for divine renewal
The image of being 'whiter than snow' (v.7) is a powerful metaphor for complete cleansing
'The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit' (v.17) contrasts ritual sacrifices with the heart condition of true worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the nature of true repentance and cleansing?
tips: David emphasizes that true cleansing comes from God's initiative (not human effort)
The psalm prefigures the need for Christ's blood to wash away sin
The call for a new heart (v.10) is the basis for restored relationship with God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The use of 'hyssop' (v.7), the phrase 'blot out my transgressions' (v.2), or the meaning of 'broken spirit' (v.17)?
tips: 'Hyssop' was a plant used in ancient purification rituals (e.g., in the Temple for cleansing of sin), symbolizing thorough cleansing
'Blot out my transgressions' means to completely erase sin from memory and records, as in the context of the law
'Broken spirit' refers to a heart that is humbled and contrite, not just external ritual sacrifices

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: David asks God to create a clean heart in him. What situation requires you to ask God to create a clean heart in you this week?
tips: Consider an area where you have been stuck in sin or unrepentant habits
Pray for God to create a clean heart by confessing your sins and seeking His mercy
Practice daily confession and prayer for a new heart (like David did)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and ask for a clean heart.
tips: Thank God for His blood that cleanses us from sin (1 John 1:7)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to create a clean heart in you (Psalm 51:10)
Ask God to give you a broken spirit (v.17) so that you can truly worship Him

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the repetition of 'you' in the deceitful person's description (v.1-3)

The emotional tone shifts from accusation to divine assurance in the last two lines (v.6-8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being addressed, WHAT the deceitful person does, WHERE and WHEN this happens, and WHY the psalmist is writing.
tips: The deceitful person is described as a 'mighty man' who boasts in evil (v.1)
The deceitful person trusts in riches instead of God (v.6)
The psalmist compares himself to a green olive tree (v.8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the deceitful person's tongue (v.3), the contrast in v.3, or the olive tree metaphor (v.8).
tips: The image of the tongue as a 'sharp razor' is powerful because it shows how quickly deceit can cause harm
The contrast between loving evil and truth is a timeless warning about the consequences of dishonesty
The olive tree metaphor shows growth and stability in God's presence, which is especially comforting when facing adversity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the dangers of deceit and the security of trusting God?
tips: David was addressing the Israelites who might be tempted by the same deceitful behavior
This psalm shows that God's judgment is certain on the wicked, but His grace and faithfulness are secure for the righteous
The psalm also points to the contrast between temporary wealth and eternal security in God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: Identify 2-3 confusing elements in this passage and provide clarifications.
tips: 'Mighty man' here refers to someone who boasts in power and evil, not necessarily physical strength
'Land of the living' is a term that contrasts with the dead (the grave) - meaning the deceitful person will be removed from the community of the living
In ancient Israel, 'riches' often included wealth and social standing, which the deceitful person trusts in instead of God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are trusting in your own resources (like money or status) instead of God
Practice letting go of that area and instead, seek God's provision and strength
Cultivate a relationship with God that grows in steadfast love, like the olive tree

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about this chapter's theme of the downfall of deceit and the flourishing of the righteous.
tips: Pray for the courage to speak truth when your tongue might plot destruction
Ask God to help you avoid trusting in riches and instead trust in Him
Thank God for His steadfast love that sustains us like the olive tree

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the context of David being seized by the Philistines in Gath
Note the enemies' actions: stirring strife, lurking, watching
Highlight God's deliverance: from death and falling

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of trust (v. 3), the recording of tears (v. 8), or the enemies turning back (v. 10).
tips: The phrase 'record my tears' (v. 8) is a powerful image of God's attention to our pain

The promise of deliverance from death (v. 10) is a profound hope in the midst of terror

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's faithfulness in times of crisis?

It points to the theological truth that God's deliverance is not dependent on human strength but on His promise

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: In ancient Hebrew, 'record' (mamash) implies God actively preserves and remembers the tears of the faithful, not just passively observing
The phrase 'lurk and watch' (v. 4) describes enemies who are patient and strategic, which was common in the Philistine context
The Christ connection: David's trust in God's deliverance foreshadows Christ's victory over death and enemies

questions.title: Application

tips: Consider a specific fear (e.g., financial stress, health issues) and how God has already delivered you from death (spiritually)
Practically, write down your tears (as in v.8) and share them with God in prayer
When you feel attacked, remember that God is for you (v.10) and your enemies will turn back

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for being your refuge when enemies attack
Ask for the strength to record your tears and trust in His deliverance
Pray for the assurance that when you call, God will turn your enemies back

questions.title: Best Bit

'Let me dwell in your tent forever' (v.5) is a profound promise of eternal safety in God's presence
'For you, O God, have heard my vows' (v.6) reflects the psalmist's confidence in God's attentiveness to his prayers

questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's refuge through this passage?

The prayer for the king (v.7) connects the psalmist's personal need with the covenant promise for the Davidic king

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: 'Rock higher than I' (v.2) refers to Christ who is above all human circumstances (as the foundation of the church)
