The prayer for the king (v.7) is a request for the anointed ruler (David) to reign in righteousness, which points to Christ's eternal kingdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'dwell in God's tent' (v.5) this week? Identify one area where you need God's refuge.
tips: This week, choose one situation where you feel vulnerable and pray to be led to the rock (Christ) as your refuge
Practice dwelling in God's presence by setting aside time for quiet prayer and reading Scripture
Ask God to help you trust Him as your permanent shelter, not just in times of crisis

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your rock and ask for strength to dwell in His tent.
tips: Thank God for being your refuge in times of trouble
Pray for courage to trust Him as the rock that is higher than your circumstances
Ask God to help you dwell in His tent (presence) so you can find peace and security

chapters.chapterTitle: For God Alone My Soul Waits

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 62:1-12 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'God alone' and the contrast between human weakness and God's strength.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'For God alone' (v.1, v.5, v.8) which emphasizes total dependence
Pay attention to the emotional shift from trembling (v.2) to confidence (v.5-6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who the psalmist is addressing, what they are saying about God, where this is happening (in the context of worship), and why they are writing this (to encourage trust in God during trials).
tips: Include the psalmist's declaration of waiting on God alone (v.1, v.5)
Note the contrast between human enemies (v.3-4) and God as the rock (v.6)
Mention the call to not trust in riches (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of waiting (v.1, v.5), the description of enemies (v.3-4), or the call to trust in God's love (v.10-11)?
tips: The phrase 'God alone my soul waits' (v.1) is powerful because it shows complete abandonment to God without conditions
The image of enemies as 'a leaning wall, a tottering fence' (v.3) vividly illustrates the fragility of human plans
The promise that 'power belongs to God, and to you, O Lord, belongs steadfast love' (v.11) provides hope in the midst of fear

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This psalm was written to encourage Israel to trust God as their only refuge during times of political or personal turmoil
The author emphasizes that true security comes from God alone, not from human alliances or material wealth
Theologically, it prefigures the Christian understanding that Christ is the ultimate Rock and salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'how long will you attack a man to batter him' (v.3)? The concept of God as the only rock? The meaning of 'power' and 'steadfast love'?
tips: The phrase in v.3 is a rhetorical question about the futility of human aggression, which might be hard to grasp in modern contexts
The term 'rock' (Hebrew: 'tsar') in ancient Israelite context often meant a fortress, but here it points to God as unshakeable
The distinction between 'power' (God's sovereignty) and 'steadfast love' (God's covenant faithfulness) is central to understanding God's character

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of waiting on God alone. What situation this week requires you to trust God instead of your own plans or material security?
tips: Consider an area where you feel uncertain (like finances, relationships, or health) and how God's promises can be your anchor
Practice waiting in silence as the psalmist does, by setting aside distractions to listen to God
Surrender your anxiety about riches to God, as the psalmist warns against setting your heart on them

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of waiting on God alone: Thank God for His rock and salvation, and ask for courage to trust Him in your current struggles.
tips: Thank God that He is the only refuge and salvation
Pray for the strength to wait in silence when life feels unstable
Ask God to help you not to trust in human systems or wealth, but in His steadfast love

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 63:1-9 aloud, focusing on the emotional intensity of the psalmist's longing.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you' and the strong verbs: 'thirsts', 'faints', 'clings'
Pay attention to the contrast between the dry land (thirst) and the abundance of God's presence (satisfaction)
The phrase 'in the shadow of your wings' (v.8) is a powerful image of protection

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist, David) is seeking, WHAT (God), WHERE (in the sanctuary), and WHY (because of God's steadfast love).
tips: The psalmist is in the wilderness of Judah (context)
He seeks God with a deep spiritual hunger and physical exhaustion
His satisfaction comes from God's presence and love

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the thirst for God (v.2), the satisfaction in God (v.6), or the clinging to God (v.9)?
tips: The phrase 'your steadfast love is better than life' (v.4) is profound because it shows that God's love is the ultimate value
The image of 'satisfaction as with fat and rich food' (v.6) is a metaphor for deep spiritual fulfillment
The declaration 'my soul clings to you; your right hand upholds me' (v.9) shows a strong, active relationship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about their relationship with God?
tips: David emphasizes that true worship and life are found in a personal, deep relationship with God
This psalm shows that God's love is the source of satisfaction and strength, not just external rituals
The psalmist's experience of God's presence in the sanctuary (v.3) is a call for the people to seek God in the same way

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The comparison of thirst and dry land? The idea of 'steadfast love being better than life'? The imagery of 'shadow of your wings'?
tips: The phrase 'dry and weary land where there is no water' (v.2) is a metaphor for spiritual desolation, not a literal desert
'Steadfast love' (hesed) is a covenant love that is more valuable than physical life, reflecting God's unchanging commitment
The 'shadow of your wings' (v.8) is a common image in the Old Testament for divine protection and provision

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'soul thirsting for God' in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel spiritually dry and seek God in prayer
Practice meditating on God's presence in the night (v.7) by setting aside time for quiet reflection
Ask God to help you 'cling' to Him in times of stress, as your right hand upholds you (v.9)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of thirsting for God and being satisfied in Him.
tips: Thank God for His steadfast love that is better than life
Ask for the strength to 'cling' to Him in the midst of trials
Pray for the grace to meditate on Him in the night watches

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 64:1-6 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the wicked's schemes and God's sudden counterattack.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'hide me' and 'shooting' (v.2, v.4)
Pay attention to the contrast between the wicked's actions and God's sudden counterattack (v.4)
The emotional tone shifts from fear to hope in the final verse

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist and wicked ones) does WHAT (pleads for protection and plots against the righteous) WHERE (in the context of worshiping Israel) and WHY (to avoid destruction from the wicked's schemes).
tips: The psalmist's plea for divine protection from the wicked's plots
The wicked's use of 'whet their tongues like swords' and 'bitter words like arrows'
God's sudden counterattack causing the wicked to be brought down by their own tongues

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: v.2 'whet their tongues like swords, aiming bitter words like arrows', v.4 'God shoots His arrow at them suddenly, and they are brought down by their own tongues', or v.6 'The righteous rejoice in the Lord and take refuge in Him'
tips: The image of the wicked's tongues as swords and arrows shows destructive speech patterns
God's sudden counterattack (the arrow) is a powerful metaphor for divine justice that the wicked cannot escape
The righteous joy in God provides hopeful contrast to the wicked's schemes

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David emphasizes God as the protector of the righteous against the wicked's schemes
The passage shows the righteous can take refuge in God and trust His justice
This communication reminds Israel that God is their shield and source of victory

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'whet their tongues like swords', why God 'shoots His arrow' suddenly, and how the wicked get 'brought down by their own tongues'
tips: In Hebrew, 'whet' (kaphar) implies sharpening weapons for attack
God's 'arrow' is a metaphor for sudden, precise divine judgment
The wicked's own speech becomes the instrument of their destruction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of divine protection from the wicked's schemes and how to take refuge in God. What situation requires you to trust God's protection this week?
tips: Identify one situation where you are being 'shot at' by others and pray for God to hide you
Practice taking refuge in God by spending time in prayer when attacked
Be mindful of your words as they can become harmful 'arrows'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the protector of the righteous. Ask for courage to avoid the schemes of the wicked by taking refuge in Him.
tips: Thank God for being the refuge of the righteous
Ask for courage to avoid the wicked's schemes through God
Pray that the wicked will be brought down by their own words as God has done

chapters.chapterTitle: God Crowns the Year with Bounty

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 65:1-7 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'you crown the year with your bounty' (v.11), 'you visit the earth and water it' (v.9), and the repeated word 'blessed' (v.10).
tips: Notice the repetitive structure of God's actions: 'you establish the mountains', 'you still the roaring seas', 'you visit the earth'
The phrase 'crown the year with your bounty' (v.11) has a strong, confident tone
The word 'blessed' appears in v.10 and v.11, showing the joy of God's provision

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is working with, WHAT He does, WHERE this occurs, and WHY He does it for worshiping Israel.
tips: Include God's role as the one who answers prayers (v.2) and atones for sin (v.3)
Note that God's actions are for the benefit of the entire earth (v.7)
The context of worshiping Israel: God is the source of all provision

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's promise of abundant harvest (v.11), the image of God watering the earth (v.9), or God's atonement for sin (v.3).
tips: The phrase 'you crown the year with your bounty' (v.11) is a powerful image of God's provision at the end of the year
The contrast between God's power (establishing mountains, stilling seas) and His care (watering the earth) shows His comprehensive rule
The promise of atonement for sin (v.3) is a key theme that brings hope to the worshiper

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God through this passage?
tips: This psalm emphasizes that God is the source of all blessing and provision for His people
It reassures the Israelites that God's mercy and provision are available to them through prayer and faith
The passage also points to God's role in the cosmic order: He is the one who creates and sustains the earth

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'crown the year' (v.11), the concept of God 'atoning' for sin in this context, and the connection to Christ.
tips: 'Crown the year' is a poetic expression meaning God brings the full harvest at the end of the year
In this context, God's atonement for sin is part of His ongoing care for His people, not a one-time event
The Christ connection: While the passage is Old Testament, it points to Christ who is the ultimate provider and atonement

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: God crowns the year with bounty. What can you do this week to trust in His provision for the coming year?
tips: Pray for specific blessings for the coming year, like provision for your family
Give thanks for the current provision in your life, recognizing that God is the source
Spend time in the Word to see how God is working in your life this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for crowning the year with bounty. Ask for the strength to trust His provision in your life.
tips: Thank God for His abundant provision in your life
Pray for the courage to trust God's provision when you face challenges
Ask God to help you see the blessings He has already provided

chapters.chapterTitle: Come and See What God Has Done

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 66:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the repeated call to praise and the Exodus imagery.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Come and see what God has done' (v.1, 8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT God has done, WHERE this praise is directed, and WHY the people are called to shout for joy.
tips: Include the Exodus (sea turned dry, passing through river on foot)
Note that God tested the people (fire and water) but brought them to abundance
Mention the burnt offerings as a response to God's provision

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Exodus imagery (v.3-4), the testing and deliverance (v.10), or the personal testimony of the psalmist (v.18-20).
tips: The sea turning dry and crossing the river on foot (v.3-4) is a powerful visual of God's power
The phrase 'you tested us, O God; we went through fire and water, yet you brought us to a place of abundance' (v.10) shows God's faithfulness in trials
The psalmist's commitment to offer burnt sacrifices (v.18) as a response to God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's actions in their history and present?
tips: The theme of God's mighty acts (Exodus) as the basis for universal praise
The assurance that God's testing (refining) leads to abundance
The call to worship and respond with burnt offerings as a sign of gratitude

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'you tested us' (v.10), the meaning of 'fire and water' (v.10), and the concept of 'abundance' (v.10).
tips: 'Testing' (Hebrew: nissah) refers to God refining faith, not causing sin
Fire and water symbolize the trials of the Exodus and current spiritual trials
Abundance here means God's provision for life and blessing, not just material wealth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you remember God's Exodus deliverance to trust Him through your current trials this week?
tips: Think of a time when God delivered you from a 'sea' of problems
Consider offering a small burnt offering (a sacrifice of thanksgiving) for a specific need
Pray: 'Come and see what God has done for me' to recall His past faithfulness

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance in the Exodus and ask for the strength to trust Him through your current trials.
tips: Thank God for turning the 'sea' of your problems into dry land
Ask for courage to trust God in the 'fire and water' of your trials
Pray for God's provision to bring you to 'abundance'

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Psalms 67 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 68:1-37 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrases of God's triumph and the call to worship.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'God' (v.1, 11, 18, 19) and the phrase 'scatters his enemies' (v.1)
Pay attention to the contrast between the scattering of enemies and the joy of the righteous (v.1, 2)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO God is doing, WHAT He does, WHERE it happens, and WHY He does it for the worshiping Israel.
tips: Include God's past action in the wilderness (v.18) as a sign of His power
Note the specific protection for the fatherless and widows (v.11, 15)
Describe the ascension with captives (v.18) as a sign of God's victory

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of the passage stood out most to you? Consider: God's declaration of victory (v.1), the earth quaking (v.18), or the call to sing to God (v.33).
tips: The earth quaking (v.18) shows God's power in the past and present, a vivid image of His active involvement
The call to sing (v.33) is a universal invitation for all nations to worship, which resonates with the theme of God's universal salvation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David and others) trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God through this passage?
tips: The passage emphasizes God as the triumphant warrior who protects the vulnerable and brings salvation
This communication was meant to encourage the Israelites to trust in God's power and care, especially in times of enemy threat

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging? Consider the imagery of 'ascended on high' (v.18) and the meaning of 'desolate' (v.15).
tips: 'Ascended on high' in Hebrew (Hebrew: 'anav) refers to God's victory over enemies and the gathering of captives, not a literal physical ascent
'Desolate' (Hebrew: 'anav) means abandoned or without a home, often used for the poor and vulnerable in ancient Israel
The phrase 'receiving gifts among men' (v.18) refers to God's provision of blessings and the establishment of His kingdom in the world

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply God's protection of the vulnerable (the fatherless and widows) to your life this week?
tips: Identify someone in your community who is a victim of injustice and pray for them
Offer to help a neighbor who is a widow or fatherless child
Reflect on how God has already 'scattered' your enemies and pray for His continued protection

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the defender of the vulnerable and ask for the scattering of enemies in your life.
tips: Thank God for providing a home for the desolate (v.15)
Ask for courage to stand against injustice and to be a defender of the vulnerable
Pray for God to lead captives to prosperity and to scatter your enemies

chapters.chapterTitle: Save Me, for the Waters Have Come Up to My Neck

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 69:1-18 aloud, focusing on the desperate cry for help in verses 1-3 and the vivid imagery of suffering in verses 4-6.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Save me' (v.1, 13, 14)
Pay attention to the contrast between the deep water (v.2) and the mire (v.4)
The phrase 'zeal for your house' (v.9) is a powerful image of devotion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is suffering, what is happening to them, where this is taking place (in terms of spiritual and physical context), and why they are calling for God's help.
tips: David's persecution by enemies (v.1-3, 5-6)
The deep water and mire symbolizing spiritual and physical distress (v.2, 4)
The zeal for God's house causing suffering (v.9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this passage stood out most? Consider: the cry for help in verses 1-3, the suffering in verses 4-6, or the zeal for God's house (v.9)?
tips: The phrase 'the waters have come up to my neck' (v.2) vividly conveys overwhelming oppression
The line 'zeal for your house has consumed me' (v.9) shows the cost of devotion
The promise of God's salvation setting him 'on high' (v.16) offers hope

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the psalmist trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's response to suffering and persecution?
tips: The psalmist emphasizes God's sovereign power to deliver from overwhelming suffering
It shows that even in the midst of persecution for righteousness, God's house is the center of hope
This psalm foreshadows the suffering servant of Christ (as noted in the Christ connection)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging? Consider: the meaning of 'waters' and 'mire', the concept of 'zeal for God's house', and the connection to Christ.
tips: The 'waters' (v.2) and 'mire' (v.4) are metaphors for spiritual and physical oppression, not literal water
'Zeal for God's house' (v.9) refers to the psalmist's deep commitment to worship, which is contrasted with the enemies' actions
The Christ connection (sour wine, the suffering servant) is a key to understanding the psalm's fulfillment in Jesus

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God's salvation setting you 'on high' (v.16) this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel overwhelmed by life's 'waters' (e.g., stress, debt, or spiritual battles) and pray for God to deliver you
Practice gratitude by singing praise (v.17) as a way to shift your perspective from suffering to hope
Share the promise of salvation with someone who is going through hardship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of God's deliverance from overwhelming suffering as described in this chapter.
tips: Thank God for His promise to set you on high when you are in deep waters
Ask for strength to endure the 'mire' of life's challenges
Pray that the 'zeal for God's house' in your heart will lead you to seek Him in times of persecution

chapters.chapterTitle: Hasten to Help Me, O Lord

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 70:1-17 aloud, focusing on the repeated phrase 'hasten' and the emotional tone of urgency.
tips: Notice the word 'hasten' appears three times (v.1, v.2, v.3) as the central plea for immediate help
Pay attention to the phrase 'O Lord, make haste to help me' (v.2) which conveys deep urgency
The shift from pleading for help (v.1-4) to the joy of God's deliverance (v.5-17) shows the contrast in emotional tone

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist), WHAT (the urgent prayer for help), WHERE (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY (the psalmist is in distress and needs deliverance).
tips: The psalmist is David (as per context) in a state of distress
The prayer is for God to act quickly to deliver him from his enemies
This occurs within the community of worshiping Israel, showing the psalmist's connection to the community

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the repeated plea for haste (v.1, v.2, v.3), the shame on the mockers (v.3-4), or the joy for the seekers (v.5-6).
tips: The phrase 'hasten to me, O God!' (v.4) is a powerful and repeated call for immediate intervention
The contrast in v.5-6: 'Let those who seek my life be put to shame' versus 'may all who seek you rejoice' shows the psalmist's hope in God's deliverance
The closing declaration: 'God is great!' (v.6) is a declaration of God's greatness that the psalmist hopes will be echoed by others

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the psalmist trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God through this passage?
tips: The psalmist calls God to act quickly in his distress, showing God as the one who delivers
The purpose is to encourage the worshiping community to trust God's timing and to rejoice in Him as the deliverer
Theologically, it emphasizes God's active help in the midst of suffering and His role as the ultimate deliverer

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'Aha, Aha!' (v.3) and the concept of shame on mockers.
tips: 'Aha, Aha!' (Hebrew: 'shema') is an expression of mockery or derision, as in 'haha' (laughing at the situation)

The phrase 'hasten to me' (v.4) might be interpreted as a plea for God to come quickly, but in the context of God's sovereignty, it's a call for God to act in His timing (as per the Christ connection)
The shift from the psalmist's distress to the joy of God's deliverance (v.5-17) requires understanding that God's deliverance brings both immediate help and long-term joy

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of urgent prayer in this passage. What situation requires you to pray for God's help this week?
tips: Consider a specific area where you feel neglected (e.g., relationships, health, spiritual life) and pray for God to act quickly
How can you practice being 'hasten to me' by stepping into a situation where you need God's immediate help?
This week, I will pray for God to intervene in my [specific situation] by saying, 'Hasten to help me, O Lord!'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your deliverer and for His urgent help in times of need.
tips: Thank God for being your deliverer and for His urgent help in your current situation
Ask God to hasten to help you in your specific need this week
Pray for the shame on those who mock your situation and for the joy of those who seek God

chapters.chapterTitle: Do Not Cast Me Off in Old Age

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 71:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and repeated phrases.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'O Lord' (appears 5 times in the chapter)
Pay attention to the phrase 'do not cast me off in old age' (v. 23) which is the central plea
The emotional shift from trust to fear of abandonment to hope

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist) does WHAT (pleads for God's continued refuge) WHERE (in the presence of God) and WHY (to avoid abandonment in old age).
tips: Include the lifelong trust from birth to old age
Note the fear of being forsaken by enemies who claim God has abandoned him
Describe the promise of revival and redemption

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for not being cast off in old age (v. 23), the testimony of God's faithfulness from birth (v. 2), or the revival promise (v. 25)?
tips: The phrase 'I have leaned upon you from birth' (v. 2) shows deep, lifelong commitment
The promise of revival: 'You who have made me see many troubles will revive me again' (v. 25) is powerful
The declaration: 'My lips will shout for joy when I sing praises to you' (v. 25) shows the joy of continued faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David emphasizes that God's faithfulness is not conditional on age or strength
This reassures the Israelite community that God does not abandon the faithful, even in old age
The theological significance: God's covenant promises are lifelong and extend to the end of life

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'do not cast me off in old age' (v. 23) - why is it a concern? The concept of 'forsake' in the context of God's promises? The revival promise in old age?
tips: In ancient Israel, old age was often associated with weakness and abandonment by God, so this plea challenges that cultural expectation
'Forsake' (v. 23) means to abandon completely, which the psalmist fears even in his old age
The revival promise (v. 25) is active: God will renew the psalmist after many troubles

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of lifelong trust. What situation requires you to trust God's continued presence in your old age this week?
tips: Consider a time when you feel weak or vulnerable, like in old age
Think about how God has been your rock from the beginning and how that continues
Pray for the strength to remain faithful even when your physical or emotional strength is low

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your rock and refuge from birth, and ask for Him not to forsake you in old age.
tips: Thank God for being your rock and refuge from birth
Pray for the strength to endure until the end of life
Ask God to revive you when you feel abandoned by others

chapters.chapterTitle: The Reign of the Righteous King

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 72:1-18 aloud, focusing on the phrases 'judges the people with righteousness' (v.4), 'delivers the needy' (v.10), and 'from sea to sea' (v.8).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the king' and the call for justice in verses 1, 4, and 5
Pay attention to the phrase 'the righteous shall flourish' in verse 14 and the emphasis on the poor in verses 4 and 10
The tone is hopeful and majestic, reflecting the king's eternal reign

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who (the king) does what (judges with righteousness, defends the poor, and has universal dominion), where (the kingdom of God and Israel), and why (to bless all nations and establish justice for the oppressed).
tips: Include the king's role in defending the poor (v.4)
Note the king's dominion from sea to sea (v.8)
Describe the king's lasting name and blessing for all nations (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the king's justice (v.4), the king's deliverance of the needy (v.10), or the king's dominion from sea to sea (v.8).

Pray for God to help you be a judge of justice for the weak and fatherless

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's judgment on unjust rulers and His care for the vulnerable.
tips: Thank God for being the true judge who will correct injustice
Pray for the courage to stand up for the weak and vulnerable
Ask God to help you be part of the solution for the oppressed

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 83:1-18 aloud, focusing on the emotional urgency in verses 1-3 and the list of enemies in verses 4-10.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'they' (v.1, v.2, v.3) to emphasize the coalition against God's people
Pay attention to the phrase 'let the name of Israel be remembered no more' (v.6) as a powerful declaration of hope
The list of nations (Edom, Ishmaelites, Moab, Philistia, Assyria) in verse 7 shows the unity of enemies

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is conspiring against God's people, WHAT they are doing, WHERE the conspiracy is happening, and WHY they are acting.
tips: Include the nations: Edom, Ishmaelites, Moab, Philistia, Assyria (v.7)
Note the plan to wipe out Israel as a nation (v.6)
Mention the historical examples: Midian and Sisera at the river Kishon (v.9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the coalition of nations (v.7), the historical precedent (v.9), or the final declaration (v.17-18)?
tips: The list of nations (Edom, Ishmaelites, Moab, Philistia, Assyria) in verse 7 shows the unity of enemies against Israel, which is both alarming and historically significant
The phrase 'do to them as you did to Midian' (v.9) connects the current threat to past victories, showing God's consistent power
The final declaration 'let them perish in disgrace' (v.18) emphasizes God's ultimate sovereignty and the shame that will come upon the conspirators

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David is calling Israel to trust God's power against a coalition of nations that threaten their existence
The passage emphasizes that God alone is the Most High (v.18) and that His people are secure in Him
This passage reassures Israel that God has historically defeated their enemies and will continue to do so

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The historical references, the specific nations, or the theological implications?
tips: The reference to 'Midian' (v.9) might be confusing because Midian was an enemy of Israel in the wilderness, but here it's used to show God's past victories
The phrase 'Sisera at the river Kishon' (v.9) refers to a battle in the time of Judges (Judges 4-5) where God defeated Sisera, a Canaanite general
The term 'conspiracy of nations' (v.5) might be hard to grasp because it's a coalition of nations that are not typically seen as unified in ancient Near Eastern warfare

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's sovereignty over enemies to your life this week?
tips: Identify a current enemy (person, group, or situation) that you feel is trying to undermine your life
Pray that God will use His past victories (like the battle against Sisera) to overcome this enemy
Remember that God is the Most High (v.18) and that He will bring shame on the conspirators

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty over all nations and ask for strength to resist the conspiracy of enemies.
tips: Thank God that He has historically defeated enemies and will do so again
Pray for courage to stand firm in the face of opposition
Ask God to help you remember that He alone is the Most High

chapters.chapterTitle: How Lovely Is Your Dwelling Place

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 84:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of longing in verse 1 and the transformation theme in verse 6.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'how lovely' (v1) expressing deep yearning
Pay attention to the valley of Baca (v6) - a place of hardship transformed into springs
The contrast in verse 3: 'a day in your courts is better than a thousand elsewhere'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the speaker and the people of God) does WHAT (longs for and seeks) in the courts of Lord, WHERE (the dwelling place of God, Zion) and WHY (for spiritual sustenance and blessing).
tips: Include the speaker's soul longing for God's house (v1)
Note the transformation of the Valley of Baca into springs (v6)
Highlight the contrast between dwelling in God's house and in the tents of wickedness (v11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the opening declaration (v1), the valley transformation (v6), or the value of a day in God's courts (v3).
tips: The valley of Baca becomes a place of springs - showing God's power to transform hardship into blessing
The phrase 'a day in your courts is better than a: thousand elsewhere' emphasizes the preciousness of God's presence
The blessing for those who dwell in God's house (v2) and the contrast with the tents of wickedness (v11) show the ultimate hope

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about the beauty and importance of God's dwelling place?
tips: David is calling the people to seek God's presence in the temple as the source of life and blessing
The theological significance: God's house is where true life and strength are found, not in the world's systems
This passage affirms that the believer's ultimate joy and strength come from dwelling in God's presence

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'Valley of Baca', the concept of 'highways to Zion', and the application of 'dwell in your house' today.
tips: Valley of Baca is a specific place in the Judean hills that represents a difficult spiritual journey, but God transforms it into springs of life
Highways to Zion refers to the paths of faith that lead to God's presence (the temple), not literal roads
Dwelling in God's house is a metaphor for being in the community of God (the church) and in a relationship with Him, not a physical location

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'the valley transformed'. What can you do this week to seek God's presence and transform your current valley of difficulty into a place of springs?
tips: Identify one area where you feel spiritually dry (a valley) and pray for God to transform it into a place of springs
Go to the local church (or God's presence) to experience the blessing of dwelling in His house
Practice the journey from strength to strength (v6) by stepping into God's presence daily

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the longing for God's dwelling place and the transformation of your valleys.
tips: Thank God for the joy of His presence in His house (the church and the temple)
Ask for strength to go through your valleys and to make them places of springs (blessing)
Pray for the desire to dwell in God's house rather than in the tents of wickedness (worldly sin)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 85:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the plea for revival and the imagery of divine harmony.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'revive us again' (v.1) and the question about God's anger (v.3)
Pay attention to the phrases 'steadfast love and faithfulness meet' (v.5) and 'righteousness and peace kiss each other' (v.6)
The closing verse (v.13) has a powerful image: 'faithfulness springs up from the ground, and righteousness looks down from the sky'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praying, WHAT God is called to do, WHERE this prayer is happening (in the context of Israel), and WHY (for the restoration of Israel).
tips: Include the psalmist's plea for God to restore the fortunes of Jacob (v.1)
Note the context of worshiping Israel (as per the original audience)
Mention the hope for God's steadfast love and salvation (v.4-5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for revival (v.1-2), the question about God's anger (v.3), the hope of steadfast love (v.4), or the imagery of 'steadfast love and faithfulness meet' (v.5-6)?
tips: The phrase 'steadfast love and faithfulness meet' (v.5) is a poetic expression of divine unity that the psalmist desires
The image of 'righteousness and peace kiss each other' (v.6) shows the harmony that God brings to a broken world
The closing verse (v.13) is a beautiful metaphor: faithfulness (from the earth) and righteousness (from the heavens) coming together to restore creation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David) trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and response to their need for revival?
tips: The psalmist is calling for God to restore Israel after a period of sin and exile (implied by the plea for revival)
The main point is that God's steadfast love and faithfulness are the foundation for revival and reconciliation
This passage emphasizes that God's character (steadfast love and faithfulness) is what will bring about the restoration of His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'revive us again' (v.1) might imply a past restoration that has been lost. The meaning of 'steadfast love and faithfulness meet' (v.5) is not literal but symbolic. The image of 'righteousness looks down from the sky' (v.13) might be confusing.
tips: 'Revive us again' (v.1) refers to a past restoration that the people have experienced but now need to be renewed (as in the context of the Babylonian exile, though this psalm predates it, it's a gener
The phrase 'meet' (v.5) is a poetic way of expressing that God's steadfast love and faithfulness are in harmony and work together
The image 'righteousness looks down from the sky' (v.13) is a metaphor for divine righteousness being active and present in the earth (as in the psalmist's understanding of God's sovereignty)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'steadfast love and faithfulness meeting' to your life this week? Specifically, how can you seek God's restoration in a time of need?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel God's presence is lacking (like a broken relationship or personal struggle)
Pray for God's steadfast love to meet your needs and for His faithfulness to restore you
Practice being still and listening for God's voice, as the psalmist does (v.1-2)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His steadfast love and faithfulness that meet in your life. Ask for revival in your community and personal life.
tips: Thank God for His promise to restore (v.1)
Ask for the steadfast love to meet your needs and the righteousness to come down (v.13)
Pray for the church to experience the harmony of 'righteousness and peace' (v.6)

chapters.chapterTitle: Teach Me Your Way, O Lord

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 86:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'O Lord' and the contrast between the speaker's poverty and God's attributes.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'O Lord' (v.1, 3, 5, 7)
Pay attention to the contrast between the speaker's poverty and God's mercy (v.1-3)
The phrase 'unite my heart to fear your name' (v.9) shows deep longing for unity

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the speaker) is seeking help, WHAT (God's mercy and guidance), WHERE (in the context of worship), and WHY (because the speaker is poor and needy).
tips: Include the speaker as a poor and needy person (v.1)
Note God's description as merciful, gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love (v.3)
Describe the request for God to teach the way and unite the heart (v.8-9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the speaker's plea for God's mercy (v.1), the description of God's uniqueness (v.6), or the request to teach the way (v.8-9)?
tips: The phrase 'You have delivered my soul from the depths of Sheol' (v.10) shows God's power over death and rescue
The contrast in verse 6: 'There is none like you among the gods' highlights God's singularity
The request to 'unite my heart to fear your name' (v.9) is a deep spiritual longing for alignment with God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's nature and response to the needy?
tips: God is the only true God who is merciful and gracious, and He responds to the humble and needy
The passage emphasizes that God's mercy and grace are available to all who come to Him in prayer, even the poor and needy
The call to 'teach me your way' shows that God desires a relationship of obedience and alignment with His truth

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of God's mercy in the context of a needy person, the meaning of 'Sheol', or the idea that God unites the heart?
tips: Sheol (v.10) refers to the underworld or grave; God's deliverance from Sheol is a promise of resurrection and salvation
The phrase 'unite my heart to fear your name' (v.9) requires deep transformation that may be difficult without God's work
The statement that 'all nations will come and worship before you' (v.7) is a prophetic promise of universal worship, which might be hard to understand in the context of the time

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the request to 'teach me your way' to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you need God's guidance to walk in His truth
Pray for God to unite your heart to fear His name by seeking His will
Surrender a specific need to God, like financial struggles or relational issues, trusting His deliverance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's mercy and guidance, asking for the heart to be united to His name
tips: Thank God for being a God of mercy and grace
Ask for the strength to trust in His provision when you are poor and needy
Pray for the unity of your heart to fear His name and walk in His truth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 87:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'This one was born there' (v.4) and the contrast between 'Zion' and 'Babylon'.
tips: Note the phrase 'Glorious things of you' (v.3) which emphasizes Zion's divine status
Pay attention to the list of nations: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, Cush (v.4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is the city (Zion) that God loves, WHAT God does (registers nations as citizens), WHERE this happens (the holy mountain), and WHY (as a sign of God's universal care).
tips: Include the city of God (Zion) being established by God (v.6)
Note that the city is the foundation for the nations to be born there (v.5)
Describe the universal scope: from Rahab to Cush (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'This one and that one were born in her' (v.5), the inclusion of Babylon and Rahab (v.4), or the declaration 'All my springs are in you' (v.10)?
tips: The phrase 'This one and that one were born in her' shows God's inclusive nature, including the nations that were once enemies
Babylon is mentioned as a place where people were born in the city of God, which is a surprising contrast to its history as an enemy
The image of 'springs of life' (v.10) is a powerful metaphor for spiritual renewal

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the city of God (Zion) and its relationship with the nations?
tips: The city of Zion is the holy mountain where God's presence dwells (v.1)
This passage affirms that God's people are from all nations (Rahab, Babylon, etc.) and that Zion is the place of birth for all who are in God's plan
The city is established by God (v.6) as a sign of His sovereignty

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to Babylon as a place of birth? The phrase 'This one was born there'? The meaning of 'the Most High Himself will establish her'?
tips: Babylon is a city that historically opposed Israel, so why is it mentioned as a place of birth? The passage uses it as an example of nations that are registered as citizens of God's city (Zion) throug
The phrase 'This one was born there' (v.4) refers to the fact that people from all nations are born in the city of God through the new birth, not physical birth
'The Most High Himself will establish her' (v.6) means that God is the one who will make Zion strong and enduring, not just a human effort

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the passage 'All my springs are in you' (v.10) apply to your life? What can you do this week to draw from God's spiritual life?
tips: Identify one area where you need to be renewed by God's Spirit (like the springs of life)
Practice daily prayer to draw from God's provision (as the springs of life)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the city of Zion and ask for the blessing of being born in His city (Zion).
tips: Thank God that He is the one who establishes Zion (v.6) and that He loves the gates of Zion more than all dwellings of Jacob (v.2)
Pray for the faith to be born in the city of God (Zion) through Christ
Ask God to open your heart to be a part of the universal church (Zion)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 88:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and repeated phrases like 'darkness', 'pit', and 'Sheol'.
tips: Note the repetition of 'I cry out' (v.1, v.10) shows persistent pleading
The phrase 'darkness is my only companion' (v.12) is a powerful image of isolation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (the psalmist), what (the suffering and cry for help), where (in the depths of the pit), and why (despite God's presence, the psalmist feels abandoned).
tips: The psalmist is in deep despair and feels abandoned by God
The psalmist is in the 'pit' (Sheol) with darkness and the presence of God's wrath
The psalmist's cry for God's steadfast love in the grave

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the repeated cry for help (v.1, v.10), the image of darkness (v.12), or the question about God's faithfulness in the grave (v.14)?
tips: The phrase 'I cry out day and night' (v.1) shows relentless hope despite suffering
The image of 'darkness is my only companion' (v.12) powerfully conveys isolation and despair
The question 'Do your steadfast love and faithfulness declared in the grave?' (v.14) is a profound challenge to God's promises

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's response to suffering?
tips: David is expressing the depth of human suffering and the feeling of abandonment, yet he holds hope in God's steadfast love
This psalm shows that even in the darkest moments, God's presence and faithfulness are real, as seen in Christ's fulfillment
David's cry for God's help in the grave foreshadows Christ's descent into hell

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'Sheol' (the underworld), the meaning of 'pit' in this context, and the question about God's faithfulness in the grave?
tips: Sheol is the Hebrew term for the underworld, not the afterlife as in some traditions, but the place of the dead
The 'pit' here (v.5) is a deep, dark place of despair, not a physical pit
The question in v.14 challenges whether God's faithfulness is limited to the living, but the psalmist is trusting in God's presence even in death

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of persistent crying out to God in your own suffering this week?
tips: When you feel abandoned, remember to cry out to God as the psalmist did (v.1, v.10)
Pray for God to be your refuge in the darkness (v.12) when you face trials
Ask God to help you trust His faithfulness even when you are in the 'pit' (v.5)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of suffering and God's presence in the darkest moments.
tips: Thank God for being present in your suffering, even when you feel abandoned
Ask God to help you trust His faithfulness in the grave (v.14) when you are in deep trouble
Pray for the comfort of Christ who descended into the pit for you

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 89:1-28 aloud, focusing on the contrast between God's ancient promise and the current lament.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I have made a covenant' (v. 3, 5) and 'steadfast love' (v. 23, 28)
Pay attention to the shift from God's power (v. 10) to the lament (v. 21-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is lamenting, WHAT God promised, WHERE the promise was made (to David), and WHY the lament is being made.
tips: David's line (the anointed) is rejected by God (v. 21)
The covenant was sworn to David (v. 5) and was meant to last forever
The lament comes from the perspective of worshiping Israel

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's cosmic power (v. 10), the covenant promise (v. 5-4), or the lament about the anointed being rejected (v. 21-22)?
tips: The phrase 'I have made a covenant with my chosen one, sworn to David my servant' (v. 5) shows the depth of God's commitment
The contrast between God's power (v. 10) and the current broken covenant (v. 21) is striking
The question 'How long, O Lord?' (v. 23) is a cry for patience and faith

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's covenant with David and the current situation?
tips: David is pleading for God to remember His covenant with David (the anointed) which seems broken
This passage shows God's faithfulness despite temporary failures in the Davidic line
The author's purpose is to remind the Israelites of God's eternal promise and to cry out for God's steadfast love

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The rejection of the anointed, the meaning of 'Rahab', or the Davidic covenant's fulfillment in Christ?
tips: 'Rahab' in this context refers to a sea monster, but the phrase 'you crushed Rahab' (v. 10) shows God's power over chaos
The term 'anointed' (mishpachah) refers to the king of Israel, but the psalmist laments that the anointed has been rejected by God (v. 21)
The Davidic covenant was meant to last forever (v. 4) but in the historical context of the exile, it seemed broken

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's covenant and steadfast love in your life this week?
tips: Reflect on a time when you felt God's promise was broken (like the Davidic line)
Pray for God to renew your covenant with Him (like David's plea for steadfast love)
Make a decision to trust God's promise of restoration in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His covenant promises and ask for His steadfast love to be restored.
tips: Thank God for His covenant with David (the anointed) that ultimately points to Christ
Pray for courage to trust God's promises even when they seem broken
Ask God to help you remember His steadfast love (v. 23)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 90:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between God's eternity and human frailty.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you' (God) in the prayer
Pay attention to the phrase 'a thousand years in your sight are but as yesterday' (v.4) which shows the vast difference in time perception
Listen for the shift from God's eternal nature to the plea for wisdom in v.12

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Moses) is addressing, WHAT (God's eternal nature and human frailty), WHERE (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY (to seek wisdom and steadfast love).
tips: Include the key phrase 'before the mountains were born' (v.2) to show God's timelessness
Note the contrast in v.4: human time (thousand years) vs. God's time (yesterday)
Mention the plea for wisdom in v.12

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of God's eternity (v.2), the brevity of human life (v.4), or the plea for wisdom (v.12).
tips: The phrase 'before the mountains were born' (v.2) is a powerful image of God's eternal nature that transcends time
The comparison of a thousand years to 'yesterday' (v.4) is a striking contrast that highlights the insignificance of human time in God's perspective
The plea 'Teach us to number our days that we may get a heart of wisdom' (v.12) is deeply practical and addresses a universal human need

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the worshiping Israelites about God's eternal nature and the need for wisdom in a fleeting life?
tips: This prayer emphasizes that God is the eternal Creator who has been our dwelling place (v.1, 2)
Moses is calling Israel to recognize their temporary existence and seek wisdom from God rather than self-reliance
The Christ connection: Christ, the eternal Word (John 1:1), became flesh (John 1:14) to live in the same fleeting time as humans, but His life is eternal

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of God's timelessness, the brevity of human life, or the plea for wisdom in the context of sin?
tips: 'Before the mountains were born' (v.2) refers to the time before creation, not that mountains were created by God in the past
The phrase 'a thousand years in your sight are but as yesterday' (v.4) is a poetic expression of God's timelessness, not a literal comparison
'We are consumed by your anger' (v.7) is a lament about the consequences of sin, not a statement about God's general anger toward all

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of numbering your days (v.12) to live with wisdom this week?
tips: Write down 3 days that you have been given by God and reflect on how to live them with wisdom
Pray for the gift of wisdom to help you make decisions that honor God
Consider a specific area where you are living without wisdom and ask God to show you how to change

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His eternal nature and ask for wisdom to live each day with purpose.
tips: Thank God for being your dwelling place (v.1) and for His eternal nature (v.2)
Pray for the heart of wisdom to help you number your days (v.12)
Ask God to satisfy you with His steadfast love in the morning (v.13)

chapters.chapterTitle: Under the Shadow of the Almighty

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 91:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'shelter of the Most High', 'shadow of the Almighty', and 'a thousand may fall at your side'.
tips: Note the repetition of 'I will say to the Lord' (v.1) as a declaration of trust
Pay attention to the contrast in verse 5: 'a thousand may fall at your side, but it will not come near you'
Notice the phrase 'He will cover you with His pinions' (v.11) as a symbol of divine protection

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the believer), WHAT (is protected), WHERE (in the shadow of the Almighty), and WHY (because of God's faithfulness and care).
tips: Include the promise of being delivered from snare and pestilence (v.5-6)
Note the angelic guardianship described in verse 11: 'cover you with His pinions'
Mention the assurance of God's presence in trouble (v.14: 'He will call upon me, and I will answer him')

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'shelter of the Most High' (v.1), the promise of being delivered from a thousand enemies (v.5), or the assurance of God's immediate response in trouble (v.14).
tips: The contrast in verse 5: 'a thousand may fall at your side, but it will not come near you' shows the overwhelming protection
The phrase 'He will cover you with His pinions' (v.11) is a powerful image of divine care
The promise of 'long life' and 'salvation' (v.16) speaks to eternal fulfillment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's protection?
tips: David was addressing the community of worshipers in Israel, assuring them of God's active care in times of danger
The psalm emphasizes that true refuge comes from God alone (not from human strength or self-reliance)
This passage is a response to the fear of enemies and the need for divine protection, showing that God is the ultimate fortress

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'a thousand may fall at your side' (v.5), the meaning of 'pinions' (v.11), or the promise of being in God's shadow without fear of night (v.6).
tips: The number 'a thousand' is hyperbolic, meaning a large number (not literal), to emphasize the scale of protection
'Pinions' (from Hebrew 'sharaf') refers to the wings of an eagle, symbolizing divine covering and protection
The phrase 'terror of the night' (v.6) and 'pestilence that stalks in darkness' (v.6) may be interpreted as spiritual and physical dangers, but the psalm assures that God's protection covers these

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this promise of divine protection in your current situation? (e.g., when facing anxiety, conflict, or danger)
tips: Practice speaking to God as 'my refuge and my fortress' (v.1) in times of stress
Trust that God will cover you with His pinions (v.11) even when you feel surrounded by enemies
In times of trouble, call upon God as described in v.14: 'He will call upon me, and I will answer him'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your refuge and fortress. Ask for the courage to trust in Him when you feel surrounded by danger.
tips: Thank God for being your refuge and fortress (v.1)
Ask for the courage to trust in Him when you feel surrounded by danger (v.5)
Pray for the assurance of His immediate response in your troubles (v.14)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 92:1-6 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the wicked and the righteous.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord' and 'righteous' in the psalm
Pay attention to the imagery of the wicked sprouting like grass (v4) and the righteous flourishing like the palm tree (v5)
Listen for the emotional tone of praise and confidence in God's faithfulness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being praised, WHAT God has done, WHERE this praise occurs, and WHY it is important.
tips: Include the contrast between the wicked (who will be destroyed) and the righteous (who flourish)
Note that this praise occurs during the Sabbath (a time of rest and worship)
Describe how the righteous bear fruit in old age as a sign of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the imagery of the righteous flourishing (v5), the destruction of the wicked (v4), or the declaration that the Lord is upright (v6).
tips: The palm tree and cedar are strong, long-lived symbols of the righteous who endure and produce fruit
The statement 'they are ever full of sap and green' shows continuous vitality even in old age
The contrast between the temporary nature of the wicked (grass) and the eternal nature of the righteous (palm tree) is profound

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage? How does this relate to the Sabbath?
tips: This psalm is a song for the Sabbath, so it's meant to be sung during rest and worship
The main point is that the righteous will flourish and bear fruit in the Sabbath (a time of rest) while the wicked will be destroyed
It calls Israel to praise God for His steadfast love and faithfulness, and to trust in Him as the one who is upright

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between the wicked and the righteous? The meaning of 'destroyed forever'? The connection to Christ?
tips: The term 'sprout like grass' (v4) is a metaphor for the wicked who are temporary and will be destroyed quickly, but it's not literal grass in the field
'Destroyed forever' means the wicked will not have any lasting existence in God's kingdom (they are removed from the world)
The Christ connection: In the New Covenant, the Sabbath rest is found in Christ (John 14:23), and the righteous (believers) flourish eternally

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on how you can bear fruit (e.g., through prayer, service, sharing the gospel) even in the midst of challenges
Ask God for the strength to be like the righteous (the palm tree and cedar) in old age
Trust that God will destroy the wicked (by His judgment) and that you will flourish in His presence

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for His steadfast love and faithfulness
Ask for the strength to be like the righteous (the palm tree and cedar)
Pray that the wicked are destroyed and that the Lord is upright in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 93:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the phrases 'the Lord reigns', 'robed in majesty', and 'the world is established'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord' and 'reigns'
Pay attention to the strong, confident tone of the psalmist
The phrase 'the world is established' appears in verse 3

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT the Lord does, WHERE His reign is established, and WHY this matters for worshiping Israel.
tips: The Lord is the sovereign ruler (not the people) who has established the world
The psalmist emphasizes the permanence of God's rule (verse 3: 'the world is established; it shall never be moved')
The throne of God is from everlasting (verse 5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Lord's robed majesty (v.1), the mightier than chaos (v.5), or the trustworthy decrees (v.8)?
tips: The phrase 'mightier than the thunders of many waters' (v.5) shows God's power over natural chaos
The declaration 'your decrees are very trustworthy' (v.8) connects to God's covenant faithfulness
The image of God as 'robed in majesty' (v.1) evokes the idea of divine authority and glory

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's kingship through this psalm?
tips: David emphasizes that God's reign is unshakeable and eternal, contrasting with the temporary nature of human rule
The psalm reassures worshipers that God is the ultimate authority who has established the world and will never be moved
This message was crucial for Israel in a time of potential chaos (like the Babylonian threat)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'the world is established' (v.3)? The meaning of 'reigns' in this context? The connection to Christ?
tips: 'The world is established' (v.3) refers to the creation order being fixed and stable by God, not the physical world in the modern sense
In Hebrew, 'reigns' (malkh) implies active rule and authority, not passive existence
The Christ connection: Christ is the King who reigns over all chaotic forces (as noted in the chapter context)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the truth that 'the Lord reigns' (v.1) encourage you to trust God's provision in your current situation?
tips: When facing uncertainty, remember that God's rule is unshakeable (v.3) and your circumstances are part of His established order
Practice gratitude for the stability of God's kingdom in your daily life
Share the message of God's reign with others who are anxious

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He reigns and His kingdom is established. Ask for strength to live in His rule.
tips: Thank God for His eternal kingship and the stability of His creation
Pray for courage to trust in His reign when life feels chaotic
Ask God to help you declare His sovereignty in your daily decisions
