chapters.chapterTitle: Today, If You Hear His Voice

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 95:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the call to joyful worship in verses 1-2 and the warning about hardening hearts in verse 11.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'come' (v.1, v.2) and the call to worship
Pay attention to the contrast between the joyful worship and the warning about hardening hearts
The phrase 'today' appears in verse 11 and is central to the message

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Israel) is doing WHAT (worshiping the Lord), WHERE (in the presence of God), and WHY (to avoid hardening hearts and to enter God's rest).
tips: Include the call to joyful worship (v.1-2)
Note the contrast between God's sovereignty (v.3-5) and the warning against hardness (v.8-11)
The reference to Meribah (v.11) as a past event where Israel hardened their hearts

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to joyful worship (v.1-2), the Creator-King declaration (v.3-5), or the warning about hardening hearts (v.8-11)?
tips: The phrase 'today, if you hear His voice, do not harden your hearts' (v.11) is a powerful call to present obedience
The image of God as 'the rock of our salvation' (v.3) is a strong metaphor for unshakable security
The contrast between the current call to worship and the past failure at Meribah (v.11) highlights the urgency of the message

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David is warning the Israelites that if they harden their hearts (as they did at Meribah), they will not enter God's rest (which is the promise of Christ, as in Hebrews 4)
The passage emphasizes that worship must be joyful and present, not resistant or unresponsive to God's voice
This passage is a call to the Israelites to maintain faith and obedience in the present moment

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The meaning of 'today', why God is warning about hardening hearts, and the reference to Meribah?
tips: The phrase 'today' (Hebrew: 'ehad') in this context means 'now' or 'in the present moment', not a specific day
Meribah was a place in the wilderness where Israel rebelled against Moses and God (Numbers 20:1-13), so it's a historical example of hardening hearts
The concept of 'rest' in this passage refers to the rest of God's people (the kingdom of God) which is a present reality through Christ, not just a future hope

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'today, if you hear His voice, do not harden your hearts'. What situation requires you to trust God's voice this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're resisting God's guidance (e.g., decisions, relationships, spiritual struggles)
Practice listening for God's voice in the present moment (e.g., through prayer, Scripture, or circumstances)
Avoid hardening your heart by seeking God's help when you feel stuck

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His voice that calls us to worship and rest. Ask for the courage to not harden your heart when facing life's challenges.
tips: Thank God for His voice that calls us to worship and rest
Ask for the courage to not harden your heart when facing life's challenges
Pray for a heart that is responsive to God's voice today

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 96:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the repeated commands to sing and the contrast between God's greatness and the futility of idols.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Sing to the Lord' (v.1, 2, 4, 5) and the call to 'declare His glory' (v.4)
The emotional tone shifts from joyful proclamation (v.1-2) to the coming judgment (v.12-13), so pay attention to the contrast
The phrase 'He comes, He comes to judge the earth with righteousness' (v.13) is a powerful declaration of Christ's return

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (all the earth) does WHAT (sings and proclaims), WHERE (the earth and nations), and WHY (to praise the Lord and announce His salvation and judgment).
tips: The call to sing a new song (v.1) as a response to God's salvation
The global scope: 'all the earth' and 'all peoples' (v.4, 5)
The coming judgment of the Lord (v.13) is the ultimate reason for the proclamation

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the command to 'sing a new song' (v.1), the contrast with idols (v.5), or the coming judgment (v.13).
tips: The phrase 'new song' suggests a fresh expression of worship that the church is to sing in light of Christ's work
The declaration about idols versus the Creator (v.5) is particularly relevant in a world of false religions
The promise of Christ's return (v.13) gives hope and urgency for the earth to rejoice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: To call Israel to worship the one true God who created the heavens and is the only worthy object of worship
To emphasize that God's salvation is for all nations and that His coming judgment will be righteous and final
This passage was written to encourage Israel to proclaim the Lord's greatness and to prepare for His return

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The dual 'He comes' in v.13, the concept of idols (v.5), and the phrase 'made the heavens' (v.5).
tips: The dual 'He comes' in v.13 is a prophetic statement about Christ's return, which is fulfilled in the New Testament
In the ancient Near East, idolatry was common; this passage challenges the worship of false gods by emphasizing the Lord's sovereignty over creation
The phrase 'made the heavens' refers to God as the creator of the universe, which is a foundation for worship

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of global proclamation from this passage. What specific action can you take this week to share the Lord's glory with someone?
tips: Think about how you can 'declare His glory among the nations' (v.4) by sharing the gospel with a friend or family member
Practice 'singing a new song' by expressing gratitude for God's work in your life
Encourage others to 'worship in holy attire' (v.9) by living a life that reflects God's holiness

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the Creator and the only true God. Ask for courage to worship Him and to proclaim His glory in a world of idols.
tips: Thank God that He is the Creator and the only true God
Pray for courage to worship Him and to proclaim His glory in a world of idols
Ask for strength to be ready for Christ's return and to live in anticipation of His judgment

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 97:1-9 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between God's theophany and the earth's reaction.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the Lord' (Hebrew: Adonai) in the context of divine sovereignty
Pay attention to the contrast between the Lord's presence (v.1-2) and the earth's reaction (v.3-4)
The phrase 'righteousness' (mishpat) appears in v.1 and v.6, emphasizing God's justice

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (God) does WHAT (reigns in righteousness), WHERE (all the earth), and WHY (to bring judgment on enemies and joy to the righteous).
tips: Include the image of God's theophany (v.3-4: clouds, darkness, fire)
Note the contrast between the earth's trembling (v.5) and the joy of Zion (v.6)
Highlight the shaming of idolaters (v.7-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the theophany imagery (v.3-4), the earth's reaction (v.5-6), or the shaming of idolaters (v.7-8)?
tips: The description of the Lord's presence as 'clouds and thick darkness' (v.3) evokes the awe of a powerful deity
The earth 'trembles' (v.5) and 'mountains melt like wax' (v.6) shows the absolute power of God
The contrast between the Lord's righteousness (v.1) and the shame of idolaters (v.7) is a powerful call to worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David was emphasizing that God's reign is the foundation of true worship and that idolatry leads to shame
The passage calls Israel to rejoice in the Lord's righteousness and to reject false gods
This is a response to the worshipers' need for a divine ruler who brings both judgment and salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The theophany imagery? The concept of God's reign? The shaming of idolaters?
tips: Theophany (visible manifestation of God) in ancient Israel was often associated with thunder and fire, but here it's described as 'clouds and thick darkness' which is more dramatic and universal
The phrase 'the Lord reigns' (v.1) is a declaration of sovereignty that might be confusing in a context where Israel had multiple gods
The shaming of idolaters (v.7-8) is a strong warning that could be interpreted as a judgment on the entire nation if they were idolaters

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of joy for the righteous (v.10-11). What can you do this week to experience God's righteousness and joy?
tips: Spend time in prayer asking for the Lord's righteousness to guide your decisions
Share the joy of God's reign with someone who is struggling
Reject false idols (sin) by choosing to follow God's commands

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty that brings judgment on enemies and joy to the righteous.
tips: Thank God for His righteousness that shames idolaters and brings joy to the righteous
Ask for the courage to stand in His righteousness and not be ashamed
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you experience the joy of the Lord's reign

chapters.chapterTitle: The Lord Has Made Known His Salvation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 98:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the joyful and triumphant tone of the entire chapter.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'sing a new song' (v.1) that emphasizes fresh worship
Pay attention to the imagery of God's right hand and holy arm (v.3) as the instruments of salvation
The phrase 'all the ends of the earth' (v.4) shows the universal scope of God's salvation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Lord) is acting, WHAT (He has made known His salvation), WHERE (the earth and nations), and WHY (to bring glory and joy to all creation).
tips: Include God's right hand and holy arm as the means of salvation (v.3)
Note that the salvation is revealed to the nations (v.4) and remembered for Israel (v.5)
The response of creation (v.6-9) is a key part of the summary

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of God's salvation (v.3), the universal scope (v.4), or the creation's response (v.6-9).
tips: The phrase 'the Lord has made known His salvation' (v.3) is a powerful declaration of God's active work in history
The image of the sea roaring (v.6) and hills singing (v.9) shows the entire creation responding joyfully to God's victory
The line 'all the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God' (v.4) emphasizes the global impact of salvation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage calls for a new song of praise because God has accomplished salvation (v.1-3)
The focus is on God's victory through His right hand and holy arm (v.3) which points to Christ
The purpose is to encourage worship that recognizes God's salvation for all nations and His steadfast love for Israel (v.5)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'right hand' and 'holy arm', the universal scope of 'all the ends of the earth', and the creation's response.
tips: 'Right hand' in biblical context represents God's power and strength (e.g., Exodus 15:11), while 'holy arm' refers to His active, righteous power
The phrase 'all the ends of the earth' (v.4) might be challenging because it implies a global scope that was not yet realized in the ancient context
The creation's response (v.6-9) uses vivid imagery that may be hard to interpret literally (e.g., the sea roaring) but is meant to show universal joy

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be part of the joyful celebration of God's salvation this week? Focus on a specific action that reflects the creation's response.
tips: Choose one way to 'roar' with joy (e.g., share the gospel with a friend, sing praises, or express gratitude in a difficult situation)
Think about how God's salvation has been made known to you and how you can respond with joy
Practice being a part of the 'hills singing' by sharing your faith with others or by being joyful in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His salvation and ask for the courage to share His joy with others.
tips: Thank God for making His salvation known through Christ
Pray for the strength to be a joyful witness in your community
Ask God to help you see the salvation of Christ in the world around you

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 99:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'Holy is He!' and the contrast between God's justice and mercy.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Holy is He!' (verses 1, 5, 10)
Pay attention to the contrast between God's justice (verse 3) and mercy (verse 4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the Lord is, WHAT He does, WHERE He reigns, and WHY the people should tremble and worship.
tips: Include: God as the enthroned King (verses 1-2)
Note the call to worship at His footstool (verse 5) and the holy mountain (verse 10)
The passage emphasizes God's holiness and His justice and mercy (verses 3-4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the thrice-holy God (verse 1), God's justice and mercy (verses 3-4), or the call to worship at His footstool (verse 5)?
tips: The phrase 'Holy is He!' repeated three times (verses 1, 5, 10) emphasizes the divine transcendence
The contrast between God's justice (verse 3) and mercy (verse 4) in the context of the people of Israel
The image of worshiping at 'His footstool' (verse 5) as a symbol of humility and intimacy with God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the holiness of the Lord?
tips: The passage calls Israel to recognize God's absolute holiness and sovereignty
It contrasts God's holiness with the idolatry of the nations and the need for Israel to worship Him as the only true God
The author's purpose is to inspire worship that is both reverent and obedient

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'footstool', the role of Moses and Aaron, or the contrast between justice and mercy?
tips: 'Footstool' (verse 5) refers to the place of worship where one stands in humble reverence before God, not the physical footstool
Moses and Aaron were priests (verse 6) but the passage is from the perspective of the people of Israel, so it's a reminder of God's covenant with them
The passage shows God as both just (executing justice) and merciful (forgiving), which is a challenge to understand how God can be both

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's holiness and justice to your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you've been neglecting God's holiness (e.g., in your relationships or decisions)
Pray for God to help you see His justice and mercy in the world and in your life
Practice worshiping at 'His footstool' by setting aside time for quiet reflection and praise

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His holiness and justice. Ask for the courage to worship Him as He is.
tips: Thank God for being the holy and righteous God who loves justice
Pray for the strength to worship Him without compromise
Ask the Holy Spirit to help you experience God's holiness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 100:1-5 aloud, focusing on the joyful and thankful tone.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Enter His gates with thanksgiving' (v2)
Pay attention to the universal call: 'all the earth' (v1)
Notice the emphasis on God's eternal faithfulness (v3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (all the earth) does WHAT (makes joyful noise, serves with gladness, enters gates with thanksgiving) WHERE (the Lord's presence) and WHY (to know the Lord is God and we are His people).
tips: Include the three key identities: Creator, Shepherd, and Eternal Faithfulness
Note that the passage calls for active participation in worship (not passive)
Mention the universal scope: 'all the earth'

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the universal call to worship (v1), the active entry into God's presence (v2), or the eternal faithfulness (v3).
tips: The phrase 'make a joyful noise to the Lord, all the earth' (v1) emphasizes that worship is a communal, global response
The instruction to 'enter His gates with thanksgiving' (v2) shows a personal yet communal act of worship that is both intimate and universal
The declaration 'His steadfast love endures forever' (v3) provides a foundation for enduring hope in God's faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God and their relationship with Him?
tips: The passage affirms that God is the Creator (He made us) and the Shepherd (we are His sheep)
It emphasizes that God's faithfulness is eternal and transcends generations
The main point is to encourage worshipers to enter God's presence with thanksgiving because they know God is both their Creator and their Shepherd

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: 'We are His people, and the sheep of His pasture' uses an Old Testament metaphor that may not be familiar to modern readers
The Hebrew term 'hesed' (steadfast love) refers to a covenantal, loyal love that is not based on transaction but on commitment
The phrase 'eternal faithfulness' (to all generations) might be challenging because it implies God's faithfulness extends beyond time, which can be difficult to grasp

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'entering His gates with thanksgiving' this week?
tips: Choose one moment this week to express thanksgiving to God, specifically in the context of His provision
Practice entering God's presence with a thankful heart by writing down three things you are grateful for
Share your thanksgiving with others to extend the community of worship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is good and faithful, and ask for the courage to enter His presence with thanksgiving.
tips: Thank God for His steadfast love and faithfulness that endures forever
Ask for the strength to worship Him with joy and thanksgiving in your daily life
Pray for others to experience the same joyful worship and thanksgiving

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 101:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'I will' and the phrase 'blameless'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I will' (4 times) showing commitment
The phrase 'blameless' appears twice (v2 and v10)
The contrast between the king's purity and the destruction of evil

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David) does WHAT (commit to integrity), WHERE (within his household), and WHY (to rule with justice and steadfast love).
tips: Include the king's promise to hate the work of those who fall away
Note the destruction of slanderers and the favor on the faithful

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the king's hatred of the work of those who fall away (v5), the destruction of slanderers (v7), or the favor on the faithful (v9).
tips: The phrase 'I hate the work of those who fall away' shows active opposition to rebellion
The destruction of slanderers (v7) highlights the seriousness of gossip in the kingdom
The king's favor on the faithful (v9) shows a clear standard for leadership

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the king's role?
tips: David is calling for a king who embodies perfect integrity and justice, not one who allows corruption or slander to thrive
This passage is a royal psalm that sets the standard for leadership in the Davidic covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'work of those who fall away' (v5), the concept of 'perverse heart' (v6), and the idea that the king will destroy slanderers (v7).
tips: In ancient Israel, 'fall away' (Hebrew: 'shav') refers to those who have turned away from God, not just moral failure
A 'perverse heart' (Hebrew: 'lebab' with a negative connotation) implies a heart that is rebellious and self-centered
The king's destruction of slanderers (v7) is a strong statement that the king will take action against false accusations

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'walking with integrity within your home' this week?
tips: Choose one area in your home where you might be setting worthless things before your eyes (v4) and commit to removing them
Pray for the strength to hate the work of those who fall away (v5) in your relationships
Seek to look with favor on the faithful in your community (v9) by supporting others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for your integrity and ask for strength to be a king of righteousness.
tips: Ask God to help you walk with integrity in your home (v3)
Pray for the courage to destroy slander (v7) when you hear it
Thank God for the king who walks blamelessly and calls you to minister (v10)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 102:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the lament and the contrast between suffering and God's eternity.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I' in the lament (v.1, 3, 5, 7)
Pay attention to the contrast between the speaker's suffering (vv.3-6) and God's eternal nature (vv.8-12)
The phrase 'I am like a desert owl' (v.5) is a vivid image of isolation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the afflicted person) is speaking, WHAT (the prayer for help), WHERE (in the context of distress), and WHY (because of God's eternal nature and the promise of restoration).
tips: Include the speaker's current suffering (vv.3-6)
Note God's response (vv.8-12: Zion's restoration and the nations' fear)
Highlight the contrast between temporary suffering and eternal God (vv.11-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the image of the desert owl (v.5), God's eternal throne (v.8), or the promise of Zion's restoration (v.16-17)?
tips: The desert owl imagery (v.5) is a powerful metaphor for being isolated and vulnerable
The phrase 'you remain' (v.25) contrasts with the perishable creation, showing God's unchanging nature
The promise of the nations fearing the Lord (v.16) is a future hope that ties to God's sovereignty

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This psalm reassures the afflicted that even in their distress, God's eternal nature and care for His people (Zion) will prevail
It emphasizes that God is the foundation of the earth and the one who will restore His people
The psalm connects the present suffering with the future restoration of God's kingdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The use of 'Zion' (v.16), the meaning of 'you remain' (v.25), or the contrast between the temporary and eternal?
tips: Zion refers to the city of Jerusalem and the community of God's people in Israel (not just a geographical place)
The phrase 'you remain' (v.25) in Hebrew means God is the same and unchanging, which contrasts with the temporary nature of creation
The contrast in the passage: 'They will perish, but you remain' (v.25) shows that God is the only eternal one

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's eternal nature and His promise of restoration to your current situation?
tips: When you feel like your efforts are temporary and you are suffering, remember God's eternal nature (v.25)
Pray for the restoration of your own life and the community of believers (like Zion) this week
Ask God to help you see the temporary nature of your struggles and the eternal hope in Him

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the same and unchanging (v.25) and that He will restore His people.
tips: Thank God that He is the same and unchanging (v.25)
Pray for the comfort of the afflicted and the restoration of Zion
Ask God to help you trust in His promises of restoration even when you feel like you are in the desert

chapters.chapterTitle: Bless the Lord, O My Soul

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 103:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'bless the Lord, O my soul' and the contrast between human frailty and God's eternal mercy.
tips: Notice the phrase 'bless the Lord, O my soul' appears at the beginning (v.1) and then again in v.2
Pay attention to the contrast: 'the grass withers, the flower fades' (v.11) vs. 'the steadfast love of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting' (v.17)
The repeated phrase 'the Lord is merciful and gracious' (v.3) emphasizes God's character

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is blessing God, WHAT God has done for us, WHERE this blessing is appropriate (i.e., in the context of worship), and WHY we should bless Him.
tips: Include the psalmist's identity (David or others) and the audience (worshiping Israel)
Note the three key benefits: forgiveness of iniquity (v.3), healing of diseases (v.3), and redemption from the pit (v.3)
The context is the worship setting (the psalm is a song for praise)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the repetition of 'bless the Lord, O my soul' (v.1), the comparison of God's mercy to a father (v.13), or the eternal nature of God's love (v.17)?
tips: The repetition of 'bless the Lord, O my soul' (v.1) creates a sense of urgency and intimacy
The fatherly comparison (v.13) is powerful because it shows God's personal care for us
The phrase 'the steadfast love of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting' (v.17) is a profound declaration of God's unchanging love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage of praise?
tips: The primary message is that God's mercy and forgiveness are available to all who bless Him
This passage emphasizes that God's love is not conditional on our perfection but on His grace
The psalmist is calling the people to a response of blessing because of God's character

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'abounding in steadfast love' (v.3), the expression 'as far as the east is from the west' (v.4), or the concept of God knowing our frame (v.15)?
tips: 'Abounding in steadfast love' (Hebrew: 'rachamim') means God's love is more than enough to cover our sins
The phrase 'as far as the east is from the west' is a poetic expression meaning God's forgiveness is complete and beyond human comprehension
God knows our frame (v.15) and remembers we are dust, which is a profound reminder of our fragility

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and forgiveness. Ask for the courage to bless Him as He deserves.
tips: Thank God for forgiving your sins and redeeming you from the pit (v.3)
Pray for the strength to remember that God is slow to anger (v.4) and that He knows your frame (v.15)
Ask God to help you bless Him with your soul as you trust in His everlasting love (v.17)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 104:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the repetitive 'You' statements and the flow from creation to renewal.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Bless the Lord, O my soul!' (v1) repeated as a call to worship
Pay attention to the description of God's creation: 'You set the earth on its foundations' (v3) and 'You make springs gush forth' (v4)
The emotional tone shifts from awe to gratitude, culminating in 'I will sing to the Lord as long as I live' (v10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO the psalmist addresses, WHAT God does, WHERE and WHEN creation exists, and WHY the psalmist praises God.
tips: Include the earth being set on foundations (v3)
Note the provision of water for animals and plants (v4-5)
Describe the role of the Spirit in renewal (v7-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's stability of creation (v3), the Spirit's role in renewal (v7), or the eternal call to praise (v9).
tips: The phrase 'You set the earth on its foundations' (v3) shows God's unchanging power and stability in creation
The description of the Spirit renewing the earth (v8) highlights God's active care for the world
The declaration 'May the glory of the Lord endure forever!' (v9) connects creation to eternal worship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God as the Creator?
tips: David emphasizes God's sovereignty in creating and sustaining all things
The passage calls Israel to recognize God as the source of life and renewal
This serves as a reminder of God's faithfulness that encourages worship and trust

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the Spirit in creation, the meaning of 'renewal', and the connection to Christ.
tips: The phrase 'You set the earth on its foundations' (v3) might be confusing in ancient context where the earth was seen as unstable, but here it shows God's control
The Hebrew word 'ruach' (spirit) in verse 7 refers to God's active power in creation, not a separate entity
The 'renewal' of the earth (v8) points to the new creation through Christ, which the psalmist anticipates

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply God's creative and sustaining provision to your life this week?
tips: Practice gratitude for the natural world and God's daily provision
Reflect on how God's Spirit is renewing your life and the world
Share a specific praise for God's creation with someone this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for creating and sustaining everything, and ask for the strength to praise Him as the Creator.
tips: Thank God for the earth and all its resources
Ask for the Holy Spirit to renew your life and the world as Christ does
Pray that God's glory will endure forever through your worship

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 105:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'remember' and the list of God's wonders.
tips: The word 'remember' appears three times (verses 1, 6, 10)
Note the emotional tone of praise and remembrance
The phrase 'wondrous works' is used in verses 5 and 10

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is remembering, WHAT He has done, WHERE these deeds occurred, and WHY He is being remembered.
tips: Include the covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
Note the deliverance of Israel from Egypt (Joseph and Moses)
Mention the cloud and fire as signs of God's presence

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's covenant faithfulness (verses 8-10), the story of Joseph (verses 16-17), or the promise of land (verses 29-30)?
tips: The phrase 'He sent a man ahead of them—Joseph, sold as a slave' (verse 16) shows God's providence even in suffering
The promise of land to the covenant people (verse 29) is a powerful reminder of God's faithfulness
The cloud and fire (verse 42) as God's direct presence during the Exodus

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David and others) trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage is a call to remember God's past deeds to encourage present worship and future faithfulness
The covenant with Abraham is the foundation for the Israelites' identity and hope
God's deliverance from Egypt is a model for how He works in the present

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to Joseph (verse 16), the meaning of 'wondrous works', and the scope of the covenant?
tips: Joseph's story is a type of Christ (the greater Joseph) who was sold and then released, but the passage uses the Old Testament context
The term 'wondrous works' (Hebrew: 'nitzavot') refers to God's miracles and judgments that are beyond human understanding
The covenant with Abraham is the starting point, but the passage emphasizes the ongoing nature of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of remembering God's wonders to your life this week?
tips: Choose one specific wonder (e.g., God's provision in your life) and write it down
Share one thing you are grateful for that comes from God's faithfulness
Pray for God to help you remember His faithfulness when you face challenges

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His wonders and ask for His help in remembering His faithfulness.
tips: Thank God for the covenant promise to Abraham
Pray for courage to trust God's provision in your current circumstances
Ask God to help you remember His faithfulness when you face challenges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalm 106:1-48 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'we and our fathers have sinned' and the emotional tone of national confession.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'we and our fathers have sinned' (v. 1, 13, 21, 28, 31, 34, 41)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from praise to confession (vv. 1-4)
The phrase 'for His name's sake' (v. 8) is repeated in the conclusion (v. 47)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Israel), WHAT (their repeated sins), WHERE (in Egypt, Horeb, the wilderness), and WHY (to confess unfaithfulness and seek God's mercy).
tips: Include the Exodus from Egypt (v. 13)
Note the specific sins: making a calf in Horeb (v. 19), yoking to Baal of Peor (v. 22)
The response: God's saving grace despite their failures (v. 47)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out most? Consider: the national confession (v. 1-4), the sin of making a calf in Horeb (v. 19), or the promise of salvation for God's name (v. 47)?
tips: The phrase 'they forgot God, their Savior, who had done great things in Egypt' (v. 13) resonates because it shows the depth of their forgetfulness
The event of yoking to Baal of Peor (v. 22) is a critical sin that led to a plague and God's intervention
The conclusion: 'Save us, O Lord our God, and gather us from among the nations!' (v. 47) is a powerful cry for redemption

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David and others) trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about their unfaithfulness and God's enduring grace?
tips: The purpose is to call Israel to confess their repeated failures and trust in God's mercy
This passage shows that God's salvation is not based on perfect obedience but on His steadfast love and the intercession of Moses (as a foreshadowing of Christ)
The theological significance: God's name is the basis of salvation (v. 47), which points to Christ as the ultimate intercessor

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The historical context of the Exodus, the meaning of 'Baal of Peor', and the concept of 'for His name's sake'?
tips: The term 'Baal of Peor' refers to a Canaanite god associated with impurity; the Israelites' worship of it led to a plague (v. 22)
'For His name's sake' (v. 8) emphasizes that God acts to honor His character, not for human benefit
The phrase 'they forgot God, their Savior' (v. 13) shows a pattern of idolatry that was common in Israel's history

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of national confession and seeking God's mercy in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you've 'forgotten' God (like the Israelites forgot His works)
Pray for the grace to remember God's faithfulness in your life
Commit to confessing your unfaithfulness and asking for God's help to stay faithful

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His steadfast love that endures even when we fail. Ask for the courage to confess and trust Him.
tips: Thank God that He remembers His people despite their unfaithfulness
Pray for the strength to avoid idolatry and to worship Him alone
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you remember God's past faithfulness

chapters.chapterTitle: With God We Shall Do Valiantly

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalm 108:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'With God we shall do valiantly' and the contrast between 'vain is the salvation of man' and God's promise.
tips: Note the repetition of 'I will' (3 times) showing confidence
The phrase 'awake, O harp and lyre' is a call to musical worship
The contrast between 'vain is the salvation of man' and God's provision

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist and Israel), WHAT (the psalmist's declaration of faith), WHERE (in the context of worship and battle), and WHY (to call for God's deliverance and victory).
tips: The psalmist is David (as author) calling for God's help against enemies
The declaration of God's promise to divide Shechem and allot Succoth
The reason: to ensure that God's people are delivered by His right hand

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'My heart is steadfast', 'awake, O harp and lyre', 'vain is the salvation of man', or 'With God we shall do valiantly'?
tips: 'My heart is steadfast' shows unwavering trust despite challenges
'Awake, O harp and lyre' is a vivid call to wake the spiritual and physical renewal
'With God we shall do valiantly' is the ultimate declaration of victory through God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and role in their salvation?
tips: David emphasizes God's sovereignty and faithfulness in delivering Israel from enemies
The promise of God's provision (Shechem and Succoth) as a sign of God's covenant faithfulness
The main point: Only God can deliver the people from the enemy, not human efforts

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to Shechem and Succoth? Why 'vain is the salvation of man'? How does God 'tread down our foes'?
tips: Shechem and Succoth are specific places in Canaan that were part of the covenant land (Genesis 33:12-14) - God's promise to allocate these lands shows His provision for Israel
'Vain is the salvation of man' means that human efforts and alliances are futile against the enemy
'Tread down' implies complete destruction of the enemy, not just defeating but eliminating

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'With God we shall do valiantly' this week? What obstacle do you need to trust God to overcome?
tips: Identify a specific challenge where you feel your efforts are failing (like a battle against sin or life's problems) and ask God to be your strength
Practice being 'steadfast' in your heart by meditating on God's promises
Commit to one action where you will trust God to deliver you, just as the psalmist trusts God to deliver Israel

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His steadfast love and for His promise to deliver His people. Ask for courage to trust Him in your current struggles.
tips: Thank God for the promise of victory through Him, not human efforts
Pray for the strength to 'awake' (become active in worship and service) when you feel discouraged
Ask God to 'tread down' the enemies of your life (sin, anxiety, spiritual enemies) through His power

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 109:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and the repeated phrase 'Let' (v10-11).
tips: Notice the phrase 'Be not silent, O God of my praise!' (v1) shows desperate pleading
Pay attention to the repeated 'Let' in verses 10-11: 'Let an accuser stand at his right hand...'
The emotional tone shifts from distress (v14: 'I am poor and needy') to hope in God (v16-17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is being falsely accused, what the accuser does, where the situation occurs, and why the speaker is praying for God's intervention.
tips: The speaker (David) is falsely accused by enemies who attack without cause
The enemies have been deceitful and have used the speaker's love against him
The prayer is for God to judge the accusers and deliver the speaker from their attacks

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the plea for God not to be silent (v1), the imprecatory prayer for the accuser (v10-11), or the speaker's condition of poverty and heart-stricken state (v14).
tips: 'Be not silent, O God of my praise!' (v1) is a powerful call for God's active intervention when the speaker feels abandoned
'Let an accuser stand at his right hand. When he is tried, let him be found guilty.' (v10-11) shows the speaker's conviction of the accuser's guilt and desire for justice
'I am poor and needy, and my heart is stricken.' (v14) resonates with anyone facing deep emotional and financial distress

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the nature of false accusation and God's response?
tips: David is calling for God to judge the false accusers and to deliver the speaker from their attacks
This passage shows that even in the midst of persecution, the believer can trust God to act for His name's sake
The Christ connection: David's prayer foreshadows how Christ, falsely accused, committed Himself to the true Judge (God)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging? Consider the imprecatory prayer, the severity of the judgment, and the identity of the 'accuser'.
tips: Imprecatory prayers (praying for punishment of enemies) are uncommon in the Psalms but are a legitimate expression of the psalmist's distress
The phrase 'Let there be none to pity his fatherless children' (v15) describes a severe judgment that might seem harsh to modern readers
The term 'accuser' can refer to both the enemy who falsely accused the speaker and Satan (as in the Christ connection)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: When you feel falsely accused by others, how can you pray like David in this passage to seek God's intervention?
tips: Practice speaking to God with the same desperation as David: 'Be not silent, O God of my praise!' (v1)
Pray for God to judge the accuser (v10-11) and for your own deliverance (v14)
This week, identify one person who has falsely accused you and pray for God to act

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His provision in the midst of false accusation. Ask for courage to be silent with God and for the accuser to be judged.
tips: Thank God for providing Christ as the ultimate sacrifice for false accusation
Pray for the courage to be like David: 'Be not silent, O God of my praise!'
Ask God to help you not be silent when you are falsely accused and to trust Him for judgment

chapters.chapterTitle: The Lord Said to My Lord

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 110:1-4 aloud, focusing on the contrast between God's authority and the Messiah's exalted position.
tips: Notice the phrase 'my Lord' (v.1) - the Messiah is addressed as God's Lord
Pay attention to the image of sitting at God's right hand (v.1) - a position of supreme authority
The phrase 'enemies your footstool' (v.1) shows complete victory over enemies

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the Lord speaks to), WHAT (the Lord commands), WHERE (Zion), and WHY (the purpose of this promise).
tips: Include the Messiah as the one who will sit at God's right hand
Note the command to rule in the midst of enemies (v.2)
Mention the eternal priesthood (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of this passage resonated most with you? Consider: the right hand (v.1), the priest-king (v.4), or the eternal nature of the priesthood (v.4)?
tips: The phrase 'sit at my right hand' (v.1) - a powerful image of divine authority and victory
The declaration 'you are a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek' (v.4) - the most profound and enduring promise about the Messiah's priesthood

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about the Messiah?
tips: David foretold the Messiah as both a priest and king, seated at God's right hand (the highest authority)
This establishes the Messiah's eternal priesthood that transcends the Levitical order
The promise of the Messiah's rule over enemies and the offering of his people (v.3) points to Christ's reign

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging to understand? Consider the cultural context, terms, or theological concepts.
tips: 'My Lord' (v.1) - The Messiah is addressed as God's Lord, indicating he is equal to God in authority
The Melchizedekian order (v.4) - A priesthood that is not of the Levites but a heavenly one, which is eternal
The right hand (v.1) - In ancient Near Eastern context, the right hand was the hand of authority and the highest place of honor

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the idea of the eternal priesthood and kingship of the Messiah to your life this week?
tips: When you feel the need for God's authority in your life, remember that Christ is seated at God's right hand and rules forever
Pray that God would help you to trust in Christ's eternal priesthood when facing challenges
Consider how your daily life can reflect the obedience of the Messiah (e.g., offering yourself freely)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the Messiah being seated at God's right hand and ruling forever.
tips: Thank God that Christ is our eternal high priest and king
Ask for the courage to trust in Christ's authority when facing opposition
Pray for the blessing of the people offering themselves freely (v.3) in your life

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'his righteousness endures forever' (v. 1, 9)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the righteous person) does WHAT (fears the Lord and delights in His commandments), WHERE (in the land of Israel), and WHY (to live in blessing and security).
tips: The righteous person's life is characterized by fear of the Lord (v. 1) and delight in God's commandments (v. 1)
His offspring will be mighty in the land (v. 2) and he will have wealth and riches (v. 3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blessing of the righteous (v. 1-3), the security of the righteous (v. 4-8), or the judgment on the wicked (v. 10-12)?
tips: The phrase 'light dawns in the darkness for the upright' (v. 4) shows God's presence in trials
The righteous person's generosity: 'he has distributed freely; he has given to the poor' (v. 9) leads to lasting blessing
The contrast with the wicked: 'the wicked man sees it and is angry; he gnashes his teeth and melts away' (v. 10-11) shows consequences of unrighteous living

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the righteous life?
tips: David calls Israelites to live in righteousness and trust God for blessing and security
True righteousness (fear of Lord) leads to lasting blessings and generosity, not fear of future
This is a call for worship community to model righteous life as response to God's faithfulness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'righteous person', the contrast with the wicked, and the meaning of 'endures forever'?
tips: 'Fears the Lord' (v. 1) means reverence and obedience, not fear of punishment
The phrase 'his righteousness endures forever' (v. 1, 9) promises secure character beyond death
The contrast with wicked (v. 10-12) shows natural outcome of unrighteous living: destruction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live like the righteous person this week? Focus on generosity or fearlessness in God.
tips: Today, give to someone in need (the poor) as the righteous person does (v. 9)

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for blessings of righteousness from Him
Ask for courage to be generous and trust God in difficult circumstances
Pray for wicked to see light and turn to God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 114:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the rhetorical questions (e.g., 'O sea, that you flee?') and the personification of natural elements in verses 3-4.
tips: Notice the repeated rhetorical questions: 'O sea, that you flee? O Jordan, that you turn back? O mountains, that you skip like rams?' (vv. 3-4)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of awe and wonder in the passage
The phrase 'the rock that becomes a pool of water' (v.15) is a key metaphor for Christ

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who God is, what He does, where this event takes place, and why it matters for Israel.
tips: Include the Exodus journey from Egypt
Note the natural elements responding to God's power (sea, Jordan, mountains)
Mention the Rock (Christ) as the source of living water

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider the sea fleeing (v.3), Jordan turning back (v.4), or the Rock becoming water (v.15-17).
tips: The sea fleeing (v.3) shows God's power over chaos and the natural order
The mountains skipping like rams (v.5) is a vivid image of God's creative power and joy
The Rock becoming water (v.15-17) is a powerful metaphor for Christ, who provides living water for believers

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's power and provision in the Exodus?
tips: God's power is demonstrated through the natural world responding to Him (Exodus)
God is the Rock who provides living water (Christ) for His people
This passage reminds Israel that God's presence transforms creation and provides for their needs

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The personification of natural elements, the connection to Christ, and the meaning of the Rock.
tips: The personification (e.g., sea fleeing) is poetic and not literal; it shows God's power over nature
The Rock in this context refers to Christ (the living water) but the passage doesn't explicitly name Christ
The phrase 'the flint becomes a spring of water' (v.17) is a metaphor for God's provision in hard times

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust God's provision (like the Rock) in a situation where you feel like the 'flint' (hard and unyielding) this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you need God's water in a hard place
Practice being still and trusting God as the Rock (like the Exodus)
Ask God to help you see the living water (Christ) in your circumstances

questions.title: Prayer

Pray for the gift of worship that leads to blessing (v.13)

The contrast between 'snares of death' (v.3) and 'delivered from death' (v.14)

questions.title: Main Point

questions.title: Prayer

Ask God to help you walk in the land of the living (v.10)

questions.title: Read Aloud

The phrase 'endures forever' (v.2) highlights the eternal nature of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is called to praise, WHAT they do, WHERE it happens, and WHY they praise the Lord.
tips: Include the universal call: all nations and peoples

The praise is a response to God's character, not a specific event

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the universal call to praise (v.1), the description of God's steadfast love (v.2), or the eternal nature of His faithfulness (v.2)?
tips: The phrase 'Praise the Lord, all nations!' is a powerful call that breaks down cultural barriers
The term 'steadfast love' (hesed) implies a deep, covenantal relationship that is active and enduring
The phrase 'endures forever' points to God's unchanging character, which is a foundation for hope in all circumstances

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author trying to communicate to the worshiping community of Israel about God's character and His call for universal praise?
tips: The author emphasizes that God's love and faithfulness are not limited to Israel but extend to all nations

questions.title: Difficulties

questions.title: Application

questions.title: Prayer

Pray that God will use you to be a witness of His faithfulness to others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 118:1-29 aloud, focusing on the refrain 'His steadfast love endures forever' (v.1-2) and the shift from distress to confidence (v.5-15).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'His steadfast love endures forever' appears in verses 1-2 and 29:1-2

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the psalmist's call for deliverance from enemies (v.5-6)
Note the stone that the builders rejected becoming the cornerstone (v.22)
Describe the declaration of the day the Lord made (v.24)

questions.title: Best Bit

The phrase 'He has become my salvation' (v.18) reveals the personal impact of God's deliverance
The declaration 'This is the day that the Lord has made' (v.24) emphasizes joy in the present moment of God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God through this passage?

To affirm that God's chosen one (the stone) is the foundation of their salvation, even when rejected by the builders

tips: Thank God for His steadfast love (v.1-2)
Ask for strength to see the stone (Christ) as the foundation of your life
Pray that the stone of your rejection becomes the cornerstone for your purpose

questions.title: Read Aloud

The repetition of 'I have stored up your word' (v.11) shows deep commitment

questions.title: Summary

The acrostic structure (22 letters) that covers all aspects of God's Word
The contrast between the sinner (who walks in the law) and the one who stores God's Word in their heart

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the opening declaration of blessedness (v.1), the internalization of God's word (v.11), or the lamp and light imagery (v.105).

The acrostic pattern (v.1-20) shows that God's Word is comprehensive and complete

This passage was a response to the need for guidance in worship (the context: Israel)

questions.title: Difficulties

'Stored up' (v.11) means to keep in the heart as a constant reference, not just memorization

Ask for the courage to walk in His law without sin
Pray for the peace that comes from loving His law

questions.title: Read Aloud

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the psalmist's distress and calling to the Lord (verse 1)
Note the enemies are described as 'lying lips' and 'deceitful tongue' (verse 2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the imagery in verse 4, the contrast in verse 7, or the lament in verse 6.

Consider how you can be a source of peace in a place where others are 'for war'

Pray for the courage to speak peace when others are for war
Ask God to help you dwell among those who hate peace but still bring peace through Him

chapters.chapterTitle: My Help Comes from the Lord

questions.title: Summary

tips: The speaker is a worshipper in Israel
The Lord provides help and protection from all evil
This is a response to the speaker's observation of the world (hills) and the need for a protector

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of help from the Lord (v.1-2), the unsleeping keeper (v.3-4), or the shade of the Lord (v.7-8)?
tips: The phrase 'He who keeps you will not slumber' (v.4) is powerful because it addresses the fear of abandonment

chapters.chapterTitle: Joy in Going to God's House

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 122:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the joy and unity in the language.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Jerusalem' (v.1, v.2, v.5)
Pay attention to the contrast between the city's unity and the prayer for peace (v.6-7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David and the worshiping community), WHAT (joy in going to the house of the Lord), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to give thanks and seek peace).
tips: David and the worshiping community express joy at the invitation to go to Jerusalem
The tribes of Israel gather in Jerusalem for worship and to give thanks
The prayer for peace is for both the city and the people

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the joy of going to the house of the Lord (v.1), Jerusalem as the unified city (v.2), or the prayer for peace (v.6-7)?
tips: The phrase 'I was glad when they said to me, 'Let us go to the house of the Lord!' (v.1) shows deep joy in communal worship
Jerusalem is described as 'built as a city that is bound firmly together' (v.2) highlighting unity and stability
The prayer for peace: 'May they be secure who love you! Peace be within your walls and security within your towers!' (v.6) is a beautiful communal prayer

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the joy of going to God's house?
tips: David emphasizes the joy and unity that come from gathering at Jerusalem for worship
The passage shows that the house of the Lord is the center of peace and unity for the tribes of Israel
This communicates that worship in Jerusalem is not just a physical act but a spiritual bond that brings peace and security

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'house of the Lord' in the context of the temple, the concept of Jerusalem as the unified city, and the prayer for peace in a divided world?

The phrase 'the tribes of the Lord' (v.2) refers to the twelve tribes of Israel, but in the New Testament, the church is the body of Christ (1 Corinthians 12:12)
The prayer for peace (v.6) is for the city of Jerusalem to be secure, but in the context of the New Testament, we pray for the church to be at peace

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you experience joy in going to God's house this week? Consider a time when you can gather with others in worship or pray for peace.
tips: Choose one day this week to go to a local church or worship space (even if it's virtual) and express joy
Pray for peace in your community, starting with one person or group
Remember that the 'house of the Lord' is where we find unity and peace, so focus on building connections

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the joy of coming to His house and ask for His peace to flow through us.
tips: Thank God for the city of Jerusalem (the church) that brings us together
Pray for peace in your home and community, especially for those who are struggling
Ask God to help you experience the joy of worship and the peace that comes from Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 123:1-7 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'have mercy upon us' and the emotional tone of plea for mercy.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'have mercy upon us' (v3) as a call for divine intervention
Pay attention to the servant analogy in verses 2-3: 'as the eyes of servants look to the hand of their master'
The phrase 'more than enough of contempt' (v3) conveys exhaustion from suffering

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is looking to God, WHAT they are doing, WHERE this occurs (in the context of worship), and WHY they are pleading for mercy.
tips: Include the contrast between the psalmist's humble posture and God's sovereignty
Note the exhaustion from 'more than enough of contempt' (v3)
The plea for mercy is made in the context of being scorned by the proud

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the servant analogy (v2), the repetition of 'have mercy upon us' (v3), or the plea for mercy in the context of contempt (v4-7).
tips: The servant analogy (v2) is relatable and shows humility in worship
The repetition of 'have mercy upon us' (v3) emphasizes the depth of need and urgency
The phrase 'more than enough of contempt' (v3) captures the emotional state of exhaustion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David and others) trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about their need for God's mercy?
tips: The psalmist is calling for mercy in the face of contempt, showing that worship must be grounded in humility and dependence
This psalm emphasizes that God is the only source of mercy for those who suffer the contempt of the proud
It foreshadows the need for Christ's mercy for those who are oppressed

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'more than enough of contempt', the servant analogy, or the connection to God's mercy in the context of suffering?
tips: 'More than enough of contempt' means the psalmist has been subjected to contempt so many times that they are exhausted and need relief
The servant analogy (v2) emphasizes that even the most humble (servants and maidservants) look to God, showing that God's mercy is for all
The phrase 'enough' in Hebrew (māšāl) implies a state of being overwhelmed by suffering, not a quantifiable amount

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, when you are facing contempt or criticism, practice lifting your eyes to God and pray for mercy as in this psalm.
tips: When you feel scorned, repeat the phrase 'Have mercy upon us, O Lord' (v3)
Think about how your actions might be causing others to look down on you, and seek God's mercy for that
Pray for God to give you the strength to endure contempt without becoming bitter

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His mercy. Ask for the strength to look to Him in times of contempt and for His mercy to come when we are exhausted.
tips: Thank God for His mercy that He is the one who provides relief from contempt
Pray for the courage to look to God even when we are being treated with contempt
Ask God to give us the patience to wait for His mercy as the psalmist does

chapters.chapterTitle: Our Help Is in the Name of the Lord

Note the Lord's active role as protector (v1)

questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?

To emphasize the name of the Lord as the ultimate trust

tips: Identify a current challenge where you feel surrounded by enemies
Pray for the Lord to be your help in that situation
Spend time in prayer asking for His name to be your refuge

tips: Thank God for delivering you from the enemy's grasp
Pray for courage to trust His name in difficult circumstances
Ask for the Lord to break the snare of your current struggles

chapters.chapterTitle: Sowing in Tears, Reaping with Joy

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 126:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between tears and joy in verses 3-4 and the sowing/reaping imagery in verses 5-6.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'sowing in tears' and 'reaping with joy' (v. 5)
Pay attention to the phrase 'streams in the Negeb' (v. 5) as a symbol of restoration
The contrast between weeping (v. 3) and shouts of joy (v. 4) highlights transformation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Zion), WHAT (the restoration of their land), WHERE (Zion), WHY (the Lord's work), and HOW (the transformation from tears to joy).
tips: Include the restoration of the temple and city (v. 1-2)
Note the contrast between weeping and joyful harvest (v. 3-4)
The call for God to restore fortunes like streams in the Negeb (v. 5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the promise of restoration (v. 1-2), the contrast of tears and joy (v. 3-4), or the sowing and reaping imagery (v. 5-6).
tips: The phrase 'those who sow in tears shall reap with shouts of joy' (v. 5) is a powerful promise of transformation
The image of 'he who goes out weeping, bearing the seed for sowing, shall come home with shouts of joy' (v. 6) is relatable to anyone laboring in hardship
The reference to 'streams in the Negeb' (v. 5) symbolizes God's abundant restoration in a previously dry place

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and the people of Israel trying to communicate about God's restoration and joy?
tips: The passage emphasizes God's restoration of Zion as a work of grace that brings joy
The transformation from tears to joy results from God's active intervention
This points to hope that God will restore what was lost and bring joy in hardship

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'sowing in tears', the reference to 'streams in the Negeb', or the connection to Christ?
tips: 'Sowing in tears' refers to laboring while weeping for lost land and homes (exiles returning)
The Negeb is a dry southern region that God restores as a symbol of new life and abundance
Christ connection: Christ wept (John 11:35) and sowed His life in death (the cross), with resurrection as the harvest

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify a situation where you are 'sowing in tears' and how you can trust God to bring 'reaping with joy' as described.
tips: Consider an area where you're working hard but feeling discouraged
Ask God to help you trust that He'll bring joy from your labor
Practice patience while trusting the harvest will come

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His restoration and ask for the joy that comes from His work in your life.
tips: Thank God for restoring your life and the church through His work
Pray for courage to trust God in hardship
Ask God to help you experience joy from reaping what you sowed in tears

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 127:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'Unless the Lord' and the contrast between 'labor in vain' and 'sleep'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Unless the Lord' in verses 1 and 2
The phrase 'labor in vain' appears twice (v1 and v2)
The contrast between 'anxious toil' and 'sleep' (v3-4) is emotionally resonant

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (worshiping Israel), WHAT (God's role in building and watching), WHERE (the city and house), and WHY (to avoid futile effort and find rest in God).
tips: Include the idea that children are a divine blessing (v3-4)
Note the metaphor of children as arrows (v4-5)
Mention the conclusion about the watchman and the city (v2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the futility of building without God (v1), children as a divine gift (v3-4), or the blessing of the watchman (v2).
tips: The image of children as arrows in the hand of a warrior is vivid and powerful
The phrase 'Blessed is the man who fills his quiver with them!' shows the joy of God's provision
The contrast between 'labor in vain' and 'sleep' highlights God's rest for the weary

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's role in their community and family life?
tips: David emphasizes that God is the ultimate builder and protector, not human effort
This passage reassures the community that God's provision and protection are the foundation of their stability
It foreshadows the church as God's building (1 Corinthians 3:9-10) and the protection of His children

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'labor in vain', the meaning of 'children as a heritage', or the metaphor of arrows?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern culture, building a house was a major undertaking for the city, so the idea that without God the effort is futile is profound
The term 'quiver' (for arrows) is a military term, but here it's used for children, showing their role in defense and protection
The phrase 'the gates of hell shall not prevail' (Christ connection) might be confusing without the New Testament context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God as the ultimate builder and protector to your family life this week?
tips: When planning a family project, ask: 'Is this building in vain without God?'
Pray for God to give rest (sleep) to your family from anxious toil
Count your children as blessings from God and share their value with others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His provision in your family and ask for rest from anxious toil.
tips: Thank God for His provision in your family
Ask for courage to trust God in your family's challenges
Pray that your children become 'arrows' in the defense of the faith
