questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 129:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'greatly have they afflicted me from my youth' and the contrast between suffering and divine victory.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'greatly have they afflicted me from my youth' (vv. 1-2) to emphasize long-standing suffering
Pay attention to the metaphor of 'plowers plowed upon my back' (v.3) which describes severe, grinding hardship
Listen for the declaration 'The Lord is righteous; He has cut the cords of the wicked' (v.4) as a turning point

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is suffering, WHAT the suffering involves, WHERE it occurs (in the context of Israel), and WHY it matters (the divine response).
tips: Include the long history of affliction from youth (v.1-2)
Note the physical and emotional toll described by the plowers (v.3)
Describe how God's action (cutting cords of the wicked) leads to the defeat of the enemies (v.4-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the repeated phrase 'greatly have they afflicted me from my youth', the plowers metaphor, or the grass withering image.
tips: The repetition of 'greatly have they afflicted me from my youth' shows the depth of suffering without losing hope
The image of 'grass on the housetops, which withers before it grows up' is a vivid metaphor for the wicked who will not mature or last
The declaration 'The Lord is righteous; He has cut the cords of the wicked' provides a clear divine victory over oppression

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage about their suffering and God's response?
tips: This passage reassures the community that despite severe suffering, God is the righteous one who breaks the chains of oppression
It points to the ultimate victory of God's people over their enemies through His justice
The theme of 'wicked will wither' (v.8) serves as a promise of future judgment on those who oppose God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts in this chapter.
tips: The phrase 'plowers plowed upon my back' (v.3) is a metaphor for severe physical suffering, but in ancient Israel, plowing was a common labor that could cause deep injury
The term 'cords of the wicked' (v.4) refers to the bonds of sin and oppression that God breaks, which might be hard to visualize without the context of ancient covenant
The grass on housetops (v.8) is a specific image in ancient Israel where grass grew quickly on roofs and withered before maturing, symbolizing the fleeting nature of the wicked

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'God cuts the cords of bondage' to a situation in your life this week?
tips: Identify an area where you feel oppressed by sin or circumstances and ask God to 'cut the cords' (v.4)
Pray for the strength to trust that God's victory over your enemies will come through His justice
This week, practice releasing a burden that has been weighing on you, knowing God has already broken the chains

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His victory over our enemies and ask for strength to endure suffering without losing hope.
tips: Thank God for being righteous and cutting the cords of the wicked in your life
Pray for courage to face the enemy's schemes without being defeated
Ask God to help you remember that the wicked will wither (v.8) and that your suffering is temporary

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 130:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and repeated phrases like 'O Lord', 'I cry', and 'wait'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'O Lord' in verses 1-2
Pay attention to the phrase 'out of the depths' as a metaphor for deep distress
The phrase 'my soul waits' appears in verse 2 and is repeated in the closing

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is crying for mercy, WHAT they are asking God to do, WHERE this plea comes from (spiritually), and WHY they are making this plea (despair over sin).
tips: Include the cry from the depths as a metaphor for extreme spiritual distress
Note the question: 'If you, O Lord, should mark iniquities, O Lord, who could stand?' (v2)
Mention the promise of forgiveness and redemption

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the cry from the depths (v1), the plea for mercy (v1), the hope in the Lord (v2), or the call to Israel to hope (v3).
tips: The phrase 'my soul waits for the Lord more than watchmen for the morning' (v2) is a powerful image of patient hope
The promise 'with the Lord there is steadfast love, and with Him is plentiful redemption' (v3) offers hope beyond human understanding
The call 'O Israel, hope in the Lord!' (v3) is a direct command to the community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and response to their sin through this passage?
tips: David emphasizes that God's forgiveness is available to the repentant, even when they are in deep sin
The passage shows God's commitment to redemption and the promise of His steadfast love
This is a call to hope in God's redemption, not in human efforts

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'out of the depths', the concept of 'forgiveness' in the context of sin, or the promise of redemption for the entire nation of Israel?
tips: 'Out of the depths' is a metaphor for extreme spiritual distress, not a literal place
In ancient Hebrew, 'forgiveness' (chatah) implies a cleansing of sin, but the psalmist is in a state of despair
The promise of 'plentiful redemption' (v3) refers to God's provision for the entire community, not just the individual

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice patient waiting for God's redemption in your life this week, especially when you feel far from Him?
tips: Spend time in prayer, asking God to be your hope and not your fear
Read Psalm 130:2-3 daily and reflect on what it means for you
Share your hope in the Lord with one person this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His forgiveness and redemption. Ask for courage to wait for Him in your season of despair.
tips: Thank God that He is the source of forgiveness and redemption
Pray for the courage to wait for the Lord when you feel abandoned
Ask God to help you hope in Him as the one who redeems from sin

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 131:1-2 aloud, paying attention to the humility declaration in verse 1 and the weaned child metaphor in verse 2.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'not' (three times) in the first clause
Pay attention to the metaphor of the 'weaned child' in verse 2
The phrase 'calmed and quieted' appears twice in the verse

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the speaker) is doing WHAT (admitting humility and seeking calm), WHERE (in the context of worship), and WHY (to find rest in the Lord).
tips: David is the speaker (as the psalmist)
He is calling for a humble heart and quiet soul
This is a prayer for the Israelites (as per verse 2)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the humility declaration (v.1), the weaned child metaphor (v.2), or the call for hope (v.2).
tips: The childlike trust in verse 2: 'like a weaned child with its mother' shows complete dependence without fear
The phrase 'calmed and quieted' is a powerful expression of inner peace
The call to 'hope in the Lord forevermore' is a profound promise

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the need for a calm and quiet soul in God?
tips: David is addressing the Israelites (the audience) in the context of worship
He emphasizes that true worship is rooted in humility and trust, not in self-exaltation
This passage foreshadows the meek and humble heart of Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'weaned child', the phrase 'too great and too marvelous', or the call to hope forever?
tips: 'Weaned child' refers to a child who is no longer dependent on the mother for milk but has a secure bond - a symbol of complete trust and safety
The phrase 'too great and too marvelous' might refer to the overwhelming thoughts or achievements that a person can't handle
The call to hope 'forevermore' is a promise that the Lord's care is eternal, not temporary

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of a calm and quiet soul to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are overthinking or worrying
Practice letting go of control and trusting God's provision, like a weaned child
Set aside time to pray for calm and quiet in your heart

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise to calm and quiet our souls, and ask for the strength to be like a weaned child trusting in His care.
tips: Thank God for His promise to calm and quiet our souls
Ask for the strength to be like a weaned child, trusting in His care
Pray for the Israelites (or the church) to hope in the Lord forever

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 132:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of David's vow and the repeated phrase 'the Lord' in verses 1-2.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord' (v.1, v.2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'I will not enter my house' (v.1)
The emotional shift from David's vow to the response of the people in v.3-4

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (David and the people of Israel) is involved, WHAT (David's vow to find a place for the Lord), WHERE (Ephrathah and the fields of Jaar), and WHY (to establish a permanent dwelling for God in Zion).
tips: Include David's vow to not enter his house until he found a place for the Lord (v.1-2)
Note the location: Ephrathah (Bethlehem) and the fields of Jaar (in the hills of Zion) (v.3-4)
Describe the Lord's oath to David that one of his sons will sit on the throne forever (v.11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: David's vow (v.1), the location of the ark (v.3-4), or the Lord's oath (v.11-12).
tips: David's vow: 'I will not enter my house' shows his total devotion to God's house (v.1)
The phrase 'Zion' is chosen by the Lord as the eternal dwelling place (v.13-14)
The oath that one of David's sons will sit on the throne forever (v.11-12)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's dwelling place and the Davidic line?
tips: David emphasizes that God has chosen Zion as His eternal dwelling place (v.13-14)
The oath ensures that God's covenant with David will be fulfilled through a son who will sit on the throne forever (v.11-12)
This points to Christ as the fulfillment of the Davidic covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The names Ephrathah and Jaar? The meaning of 'the Lord swore to David a sure oath'? The concept of 'Zion'?
tips: Ephrathah refers to Bethlehem (v.3), and Jaar is a field in the hills of Zion (v.4)
The oath is a promise that David's line will rule forever, but it is fulfilled by Christ (v.11-12)
Zion is the mountain of Jerusalem, where God's presence is established (v.13-14)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: As a Christian, how can you apply the theme of David's zeal for God's house in your life this week?
tips: Consider building a place of worship in your home (e.g., family prayer, worship) as David did
Think about how you can serve in the church (the 'house of God') this week
Pray for the Lord to choose you as part of His dwelling place

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for choosing Zion as His dwelling place and for the eternal throne of Christ.
tips: Thank God for choosing Zion as His dwelling place
Ask for the courage to build His house in your life
Pray for the coming of the Messiah who will sit on the eternal throne

chapters.chapterTitle: How Good and Pleasant Is Unity

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 133:1-3 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'how good and pleasant' and the imagery of oil and dew.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'how good and pleasant' in the first clause
Pay attention to the anointing oil imagery (on Aaron's beard) and the dew from Hermon
The phrase 'life forevermore' appears at the end as the promised blessing

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (brothers in Israel), WHAT (dwell in unity), WHERE (the community of worship), and WHY (it brings the Lord's blessing).
tips: The psalmist is David addressing the community of worshiping Israel
Unity is the foundation for the Lord's blessing
The blessing is life forevermore as commanded by the Lord

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the oil imagery (v.2), the dew of Hermon (v.3), or the promised blessing (v.3).
tips: The oil on Aaron's beard symbolizes the anointing of the leadership in the community
The dew from Hermon falling on Zion shows a natural, refreshing blessing that comes from the Lord
The promise of 'life forevermore' is the ultimate reward of unity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the value of unity in the community of faith?
tips: David emphasizes that unity in the community of worship brings the Lord's blessing (life forevermore)
This unity is a sign of God's covenant with His people
The blessing is not just temporary but eternal, pointing to Christ as the anointed one

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'precious oil', 'dew of Hermon', and how unity relates to eternal life.
tips: In ancient Israel, anointing oil was used for priests and kings, so it symbolizes the Holy Spirit's presence in the community
The dew from Hermon is a natural phenomenon that falls on the mountains of Zion (the city of God), showing a blessing that is both local and divine
The phrase 'life forevermore' is a promise that goes beyond the physical life, pointing to eternal life through Christ

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you foster brotherly unity in your community this week, as described in this passage?
tips: Choose one person to have a conversation about unity in your small group or church
Pray for the Holy Spirit to pour out the dew of Hermon on your community
Reflect on how your actions today can be like the oil that runs down the beard of Aaron

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for unity and the blessing of life forevermore in your community.
tips: Thank God for the blessing of unity in the church
Ask for the Holy Spirit to pour out the dew of Hermon on your community
Pray for the anointing of leaders to bring the blessing of life forevermore

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 134:1-3 aloud, paying attention to the call to bless the Lord and the lifting of hands in worship.
tips: Note the repetition of 'bless the Lord' in the first two verses
The phrase 'stand by night' indicates the night watch

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the night servants of the Lord), WHAT (bless the Lord by lifting hands), WHERE (in the house of the Lord), and WHY (to receive blessing from the Creator).
tips: The night servants are the worshipers who stand guard at night in the temple
Lifting hands is a gesture of blessing and worship
The blessing comes from Zion (the holy city) and the Creator of heaven and earth

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to bless the Lord (v1), lifting hands (v2), or the blessing from Zion (v3).
tips: The phrase 'stand by night' shows the commitment of worshipers who serve through the night
Lifting hands to the holy place is a physical act of devotion that connects to the divine
The blessing from 'Zion' (the holy city) and the Creator of heaven and earth emphasizes the divine origin of blessing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage emphasizes that worshipers who stand watch at night receive blessing from the Creator
It connects the act of worship (blessing) with the source of blessing (Zion and the Maker of heaven and earth)
David is reminding the community that their continuous worship leads to divine blessing

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'Zion', the concept of 'blessing from the Creator', or the night watch duty?
tips: Zion refers to the holy city of Jerusalem and the dwelling place of God in the Old Testament
The phrase 'bless the Lord' in this context is a call to actively participate in worship, not just passive receiving
The night watch in the temple was a specific duty of the Levites and others, so it's not a general night activity

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage this week? Consider: who are you 'standing by night' for in your life, and how can you lift your hands to bless the Lord?
tips: Identify one area where you are serving others at night (e.g., prayer, study) and bless the Lord for it
Pray for God's blessing on your service, especially when it's difficult or at night
Lift your hands to the Lord in worship at least once a day

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He blesses His servants who stand by night in His house. Ask for the courage to worship and receive His blessing.
tips: Thank God for blessing you as a servant who stands by night in His house
Ask for the strength to lift your hands in worship even when it's hard
Pray that God will bless you from Zion (His holy city) and the Creator of heaven and earth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalm 135:1-16 aloud, focusing on the repetition of 'Praise the Lord' and the phrases 'the Lord has chosen Jacob', 'He it is who makes clouds rise', and 'He struck down the firstborn of Egypt'.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Praise the Lord' (v.1, 3, 5, 8, 11, 13, 15, 16)
Pay attention to the contrast between God's power (v.6) and the idols of nations (v.14)
The emotional tone shifts from joyful praise to a declaration of God's sovereignty

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO God is working with, WHAT He does, WHERE His power is demonstrated, and WHY He acts as He does in this passage.
tips: Include the chosen people (Jacob/Israel) as God's special possession (v.4)
Note the Exodus events (struck down firstborn of Egypt, signs against Pharaoh) as God's historical power (v.8)
Mention the contrast between God's creation (clouds, wind) and the false gods (idols made of silver and gold) (v.6, 14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's choice of Jacob (v.4), God's power in nature (v.6), or the Exodus deliverance (v.8).
tips: The phrase 'the Lord has chosen Jacob for Himself' (v.4) shows God's sovereign election of His people, which is a foundation for worship
The description of God as the one who 'makes clouds rise, sends lightning and wind' (v.6) highlights His control over natural forces, a powerful reminder of His omnipotence
The account of God striking down the firstborn of Egypt (v.8) is a vivid example of His power in history and the deliverance of Israel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and actions?
tips: David and the Israelites were emphasizing God's sovereignty as the Creator and Redeemer of His chosen people
This passage serves as a reminder that God's power is not limited to the present but has been demonstrated throughout history (Exodus) and continues in the present (creation)
The contrast with idols (v.14) underscores that true worship is for the living God, not for lifeless objects

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'chosen Jacob', the historical context of the Exodus, and the contrast with idols.
tips: In Hebrew, 'Jacob' refers to the people of Israel (the covenant community), not the individual Jacob from Genesis
The Exodus events (v.8) are a historical memory that God uses to demonstrate His power and to remind the people of His deliverance
The idols of nations are described as 'silver and gold' but are lifeless, while the Lord is the living God who creates and sustains

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's sovereign power in your life this week?
tips: When facing a situation where you don't understand God's plan, pray for the same trust that God showed in the Exodus (v.8) - that He will deliver you through His power
Surrender your worries to God, knowing that He is the one who makes clouds rise and sends lightning and wind (v.6) - He is in control
Avoid making your worship focused on material things (idols) by intentionally focusing on God's character and power

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His power and sovereignty, and ask for courage to trust Him in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God for choosing you (like Jacob/Israel) and for His power to deliver (v.8)
Pray for courage to trust God in the midst of trials, knowing He is the one who makes clouds rise and sends lightning and wind (v.6)
Ask God to help you avoid the false worship of idols (material possessions, worldly power) and to focus on Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 136:1-41 aloud, focusing on the repetition of the refrain 'His steadfast love endures forever' and the flow of thanksgiving for God's acts.
tips: Notice the refrain 'His steadfast love endures forever' appears 13 times (each verse ends with it)
Pay attention to the structure: each verse (or pair of verses) describes a specific act of God, followed by the refrain

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (God) is doing WHAT (providing steadfast love) in WHERE (throughout history) and WHY (to bless and redeem His people).
tips: Include God's creation of the heavens and earth (v. 3-4)
Include God's deliverance of Israel from Egypt (v. 11-12)
Include God's remembrance of Israel in their low estate (v. 16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this passage stood out most? Consider the refrain, the act of God remembering us in low estate, or the rescue from foes.
tips: The refrain 'His steadfast love endures forever' is the heart of the psalm - it's repeated 13 times to emphasize eternal love
The phrase 'He remembered us in our low estate' (v. 16) shows God's intimate care for the humble and fallen
The promise 'He rescues us from our foes' (v. 17) provides hope in times of danger

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (David) trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's steadfast love?
tips: David is reminding Israel that God's love is unchanging and eternal, which has been demonstrated throughout history
This love is the foundation of their salvation and ongoing provision
The refrain 'endures forever' points to God's faithfulness beyond human time

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, Hebrew terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The refrain is repeated 13 times in the Hebrew, but the English translation uses 'His steadfast love endures forever' - the original Hebrew might have a more poetic repetition
The phrase 'He remembered us in our low estate' (v. 16) uses a Hebrew term that means 'to call to mind' or 'to have in mind', indicating God's active care for the humble
The connection to Christ: The psalm's refrain is fulfilled in Jesus, who is God's steadfast love made flesh (as per the Christ Connection), but the psalm itself is pre-Christian

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage's theme of God's steadfast love that endures forever this week?
tips: When you feel low or in trouble, remember that God has remembered you and will rescue you (v. 16-17)
Pray for courage to trust God's provision when you are in a difficult situation
Share the promise of His steadfast love with someone who is going through hardship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's steadfast love that endures forever, specifically for your current situation.
tips: Thank God for remembering you in your low estate and rescuing you from your foes
Ask for strength to trust His steadfast love when you face challenges
Pray that God's love will be your refuge in the midst of trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 137:1-9 aloud, paying attention to the lament tone and repeated phrases.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'we' (the exiles) and the lament
Pay attention to the contrast between the river of Babylon and Zion
The phrase 'how shall we sing the Lord's song in a foreign land' (v.4) is a key emotional point

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the exiles) is doing WHAT (lamenting), WHERE (Babylon), and WHY (because they are in exile and long for Zion).
tips: Include the context: they are in Babylon after the Babylonian exile
Note the specific actions: sitting by the rivers, hanging lyres on willows, being forced to sing songs of Zion
Mention the emotional response: inability to sing the Lord's song

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lament for Zion (v.1-2), the inability to sing (v.4), or the imprecation against Babylon (v.9)?
tips: The image of hanging lyres on willows (v.2) shows the loss of their instruments of worship
The rhetorical question 'How shall we sing the Lord's song in a foreign land?' (v.4) captures the heart of the exile
The imprecation against Babylon (v.9) shows their anger and desire for justice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the exiles trying to communicate to God (and to their own community) about their situation in Babylon?
tips: They are expressing deep longing for Zion and the Temple
They are pleading with God to remember Jerusalem and the nation
The passage also shows the exiles' hope that Christ would end the exile (as per Christ connection)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The imprecation against Babylon (v.9), the meaning of 'Zion', or the use of 'foreign land'?
tips: Imprecation (v.9) is a curse against the enemy, which is common in the Old Testament but might be confusing for modern readers
Zion refers to the city of Jerusalem and the Temple, not just the land
The phrase 'foreign land' (v.4) refers to the Babylonian exile, which was a common experience for the Israelites

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the longing for God's presence (as expressed in this passage) to your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel far from God (like the exiles in Babylon)
Pray for the strength to remember God's promises and not let your heart turn away from Him
Spend time in worship that centers on God's presence, not on the world

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the longing for Zion and the imprecation against Babylon.
tips: Thank God for His promise to bring us home (heavenly Zion)
Ask for the courage to remember Jerusalem (God's presence) even in difficult times
Pray for the strength to be a blessing to others, as the exiles prayed for the Edomites (v.8)

chapters.chapterTitle: The Lord Will Fulfill His Purpose

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 138:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of gratitude in the opening verses and the promise of God's preservation in trouble.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I' in the first person (vv. 1-2) showing wholehearted devotion
Pay attention to the phrase 'your steadfast love and faithfulness' (v.2) as a key expression of God's character
The phrase 'the Lord will fulfill His purpose for me' (v.8) is a powerful declaration of trust

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist) does WHAT (gives thanks), WHERE (in the context of worship), and WHY (because of God's steadfast love and faithfulness).
tips: The psalmist is expressing gratitude to God for His faithfulness and love
The context is worshiping in the temple (v.2)
The reason for thanksgiving is God's response to the psalmist's call and His preservation in trouble (v.4,7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the declaration of God's exaltation of His name and word (v.3), the promise of God's response to the psalmist (v.4), or the assurance of God's preservation in trouble (v.7)?
tips: The phrase 'you preserve my life' (v.7) shows God's active care in the midst of adversity
The promise that 'the Lord will fulfill His purpose for me' (v.8) is a profound declaration of trust
The declaration that 'your steadfast love endures forever' (v.8) connects the present to eternal love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David is affirming that God's steadfast love and faithfulness are the foundation for worship
The passage emphasizes that God's purpose for the psalmist is fulfilled through His love and faithfulness
This passage also points to God's sovereignty over all nations (v.5) and His care for the humble

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'the Lord will fulfill His purpose for me' (v.8) might seem personal, but it's part of a larger context of God's faithfulness. The phrase 'do not forsake the work of your hands' (v.9) is a command that may be interpreted in both a literal and spiritual sense.
tips: 'Fulfill His purpose' (v.8) refers to God's plan for the psalmist's life, not a specific event
'The work of your hands' (v.9) refers to God's creation and redemption (cf. Genesis 1:26-27 and Ephesians 2:10)
The phrase 'the Lord is high' (v.6) means God's exalted position but also His accessibility to the humble

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God preserving us in trouble as in verse 7. What situation requires you to trust God's preservation this week?
tips: Consider a time when you feel surrounded by trouble and ask God to preserve you
Pray that God will fulfill His purpose for you (v.8) and that His steadfast love endures forever
Practice gratitude for God's preservation by writing down three things He has done for you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He preserves us and fulfills His purpose for us. Ask for the strength to trust His preservation in difficult times.
tips: Thank God for preserving your life in the midst of trouble (v.7)
Pray that God will fulfill His purpose for you (v.8) and that His steadfast love endures forever
Ask God not to forsake the work of His hands (v.9) in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 139:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'you' (God) and the emotional tone of awe and intimacy.
tips: Notice the phrase 'fearfully and wonderfully made' (v7) which is a declaration of God's creative power
Pay attention to the rhetorical questions in verses 5-6: 'Where shall I go from your Spirit?' and 'If I ascend to heaven...'
Notice the repetition of 'you' as the subject of God's knowledge

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: Who is being described, what God knows about the person, where this knowledge exists, and why God's knowledge matters.
tips: Include the three rhetorical questions in verses 5-6 about God's omnipresence
Note the formation of the person in the womb (v6)
Highlight the call to be searched (v10) as a key action for the person

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this passage stood out most to you? Consider: 'I am fearfully and wonderfully made' (v7), 'How precious to me are your thoughts, O God!' (v9), or 'Search me, O God, and know my heart!' (v10).
tips: 'I am fearfully and wonderfully made' (v7) resonates because it affirms the unique value of each person in God's creation
'How precious to me are your thoughts, O God!' (v9) is profound because it shows the depth of God's thoughts and the person's need for God's guidance
'Search me, O God, and know my heart!' (v10) is a call for intimate relationship and self-examination

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about God's knowledge and presence?
tips: David emphasizes that God's knowledge is complete and inescapable, so the person should not seek to hide from God
This passage foreshadows Christ as the 'fearfully and wonderfully made' (John 1:14) and the ultimate search of the heart by the Holy Spirit
The main point is that God's knowledge leads to the person being led in the way everlasting (v11)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, Hebrew terms, or theological concepts.
tips: 'Sheol' (v5) refers to the grave or underworld in ancient Hebrew, not the same as hell; it shows God's presence even in death
'Unformed substance' (v8) describes the state of the person before birth, when God was forming them spiritually
The concept of God's omnipresence (v5) is not physical but spiritual and eternal, meaning God is present in all places without limitation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to be searched (v10) this week?
tips: This week, ask God to search your heart and reveal any areas where you are hiding from Him
Be specific about one thing you want to let go of or surrender to God
Practice the humility of trusting God's search and guidance in your daily decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about being 'fearfully and wonderfully made' and how God knows you.
tips: Thank God for knowing you completely and for being fearfully and wonderfully made
Ask God to search your heart and lead you in the way everlasting (v11)
Pray for the courage to be transparent with God and to surrender to His search

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 140:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'preserve me' and the vivid imagery of the serpent's tongue.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'preserve me' (v.1 and v.4) showing the plea for protection
Pay attention to the serpent's tongue and asps (v.3) as a metaphor for deceitful speech
The phrase 'cover my head in the day of battle' (v.7) is a specific request for divine protection

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the psalmist is pleading for protection, WHAT he asks God to do, WHERE this conflict occurs (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY he is making this plea.
tips: Include the violent men who plan evil and stir up wars (v.2)
Note the psalmist's plea for God to cover his head in battle (v.7)
The psalmist's confidence that God will maintain the cause of the afflicted (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the serpent tongue metaphor (v.3), the hidden trap (v.5), or the declaration of God's vindication (v.10)?
tips: The serpent's tongue and asps (v.3) is a vivid image of deceitful speech that cuts deep
The hidden trap and snares (v.5) show the active threat the psalmist faces
The confident statement that God will maintain the cause of the afflicted (v.10) is a powerful assurance of divine justice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the psalmist trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God's character and action in the face of violent enemies?
tips: The psalmist emphasizes God as the protector of the afflicted and the one who delivers from evil men
The psalmist's trust in God (v.6) and the promise of vindication (v.9-10) are central
This passage points to Christ who conquers the serpent's venom and covers us in battle

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The specific imagery of the serpent and asps? The meaning of 'cover my head'? The concept of God maintaining the cause of the afflicted?
tips: The phrase 'serpent's tongue' (v.3) is a metaphor for deceitful speech, common in ancient Near Eastern literature
'Cover my head in battle' (v.7) is a metaphor for protection in times of conflict, not literal
The phrase 'the cause of the afflicted' (v.10) refers to the righteous cause of the oppressed, which God will uphold

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God's protection from violent men in your current situation?
tips: Identify a specific enemy or situation where you feel threatened by deception or violence
Pray for God to cover your head (v.7) in the day of battle
Ask God to grant not the desires of the wicked (v.8) in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your protector and ask for His help in the face of violent enemies.
tips: Thank God for being your God (v.6) and covering you in battle
Pray for God to grant not the desires of the wicked (v.8) in your life
Ask God to maintain the cause of the afflicted (v.10) in the world

chapters.chapterTitle: Set a Guard Over My Mouth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 141:1-9 aloud, paying attention to the plea for God's attention and the request for a guard on the mouth.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'O Lord' (three times) and the plea for haste
Pay attention to the contrast between the speaker's vulnerability ('hasten to me') and the request for protection of the mouth
The phrase 'mischief of their lips' (v.7) is a strong image of deception

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the speaker) does WHAT (prays for protection), WHERE (in the context of worship), and WHY (to avoid evil and find refuge in God).
tips: The speaker is a worshiping Israelite (as per context)
The prayer is for God to guard the speaker's mouth and heart from evil
The speaker seeks refuge in God when surrounded by potential enemies

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the request for a guard on the mouth (v.4), the warning about the 'mischief of their lips' (v.7), or the plea for eyes toward God (v.9)?
tips: The phrase 'Set a guard over my mouth' is a powerful metaphor for self-control in speech
The image of 'heads of those who surround me being covered with the mischief of their lips' shows the speaker's awareness of deception around them
The closing line 'O Lord, my eyes are toward you; in you I seek refuge' emphasizes the speaker's complete dependence on God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about the importance of guarding one's speech and heart?
tips: David addresses the community of worshipers who are vulnerable to sin and deception
The main point is that true worship requires inner integrity and self-control, especially in speech
This passage connects to the theme of Christ as the perfect sacrifice and the need for believers to live in obedience

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'mischief of their lips' (v.7), the concept of 'oil of the righteous' (v.6), and the reference to 'judges being thrown over the cliff' (v.8)?
tips: 'Mischief of their lips' refers to the harmful consequences of deceitful speech, not just the words themselves
The 'oil of the righteous' is a metaphor for the blessing of God's righteousness that protects the righteous (as in Psalm 29:10)
The phrase 'judges being thrown over the cliff' is an idiom for the downfall of the wicked who are unjust

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you set a guard over your mouth this week? Focus on the theme of guarding speech to avoid evil.
tips: Choose one moment when you might have spoken out of anger or pride and practice speaking gently instead
Write down three things you can say that are kind and truthful to someone who is struggling
Pray for God to help you guard your mouth from speaking evil, especially in difficult conversations

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for setting a guard over your mouth and keep you from evil speech.
tips: Ask God to help you resist the temptation to speak evil and to guard your heart
Thank God for His protection and for being the refuge when we are vulnerable
Pray for the strength to be a source of peace and truth in your relationships

chapters.chapterTitle: No One Cares for My Soul

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalm 142:1-8 aloud, paying attention to the desperate tone and repeated phrases.
tips: Notice the phrase 'no one cares for my soul' (v.5) which conveys deep isolation
Pay attention to the repeated cry 'I cry to you, O Lord' (v.7) showing urgency
The phrase 'you know my way' (v.4) reveals trust in God's understanding

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is crying out, what they are asking for, where they are in distress, and why they feel abandoned.
tips: David is the one experiencing deep distress and abandonment
He is crying for mercy and deliverance from his persecutors
He feels hidden in a trap and without human help

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'no one cares for my soul' (v.5), the declaration 'You are my refuge' (v.7), or the promise of the righteous surrounding (v.8).
tips: The phrase 'no one cares for my soul' (v.5) captures the feeling of utter abandonment that many experience
The declaration 'You are my refuge, my portion in the land of the living' (v.7) is a powerful reminder of God's role as our ultimate safety
The promise 'the righteous will surround me' (v.8) offers hope of God's deliverance and community

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David trying to communicate to the worshiping Israel about his need for God's refuge when he feels abandoned by his own people?
tips: David is expressing the universal human experience of feeling alone and in need of God's help
This passage emphasizes that God is the only true refuge and portion when we are in distress
It points to God's faithfulness in delivering the righteous even when we feel surrounded by enemies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'no one cares for my soul', the concept of 'prison' in a spiritual sense, and the promise of 'the righteous surrounding'?
tips: 'No one cares for my soul' (v.5) uses a strong Hebrew term for abandonment that might not be easily understood in modern contexts
The 'prison' in v.8 refers to a spiritual or emotional state of confinement, not necessarily a physical prison
'The righteous will surround me' (v.8) means that God will bring a community of believers to help and protect, not just the righteous as a group in the sense of the church today

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice trusting God as your refuge when you feel abandoned and in need of deliverance this week?
tips: When you feel like no one cares for your soul, take a moment to cry out to God as your refuge (like David did)
Ask God to deliver you from your persecutors and to have the righteous surround you
This week, when you are in a trap (emotional, spiritual, or relational), remember that God knows your way and will provide

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is your refuge when you feel abandoned. Ask for strength to trust Him in your distress.
tips: Thank God for being your refuge and portion in the land of the living
Ask God to deliver you from your persecutors and to bring the righteous around you
Pray for the strength to trust God when you feel alone

chapters.chapterTitle: Teach Me to Do Your Will

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 143:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional plea and repeated phrases like 'O Lord' and 'teach me'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'O Lord' (verses 1, 3, 4, 5, 10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the psalmist) does WHAT (pleads for mercy and help), WHERE (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY (because the psalmist feels crushed by enemies and is spiritually dry).
tips: Include the psalmist's condition: 'the enemy has crushed my life to the ground'
Note the plea for God's mercy and the fact that no one is righteous
Mention the request for God's Spirit to lead the psalmist

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the spiritual thirst (v. 5), the plea for mercy (v. 1-2), or the request to be taught by God's Spirit (v. 10).
tips: The phrase 'my soul thirsts for you like a parched land' (v. 5) powerfully conveys spiritual dryness and need for God
The line 'Teach me to do your will, for you are my God!' (v. 10) is the climax of the plea and shows the psalmist's trust in God
The repetition of 'O Lord' (v. 1, 3, 4, 5, 10) emphasizes the psalmist's desperate need for God's attention

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: David is emphasizing that only through God's Spirit can we be taught to do His will, because we are all sinners (no one righteous)
This passage calls for a deep reliance on God's mercy and the Spirit's guidance in a time of spiritual distress
The theological significance: Christ is the only one who can make us righteous and lead us in His will

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The statement that 'no one living is righteous', the meaning of 'level ground', and the role of the enemy.
tips: 'No one living is righteous before you' (v. 3) is a strong statement about human sinfulness, but it's a plea for God not to judge the psalmist (who is already in a state of sin)
'Level ground' (v. 10) is a metaphor for a path of obedience without obstacles, contrasting with the rocky path of sin
The enemy here is likely the result of sin and the enemy of God (Satan), but in the context of the psalm, it's the psalmist's suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, ask God to teach you one specific area where you need to align with His will, and commit to following His Spirit's guidance.
tips: Identify a decision or habit where you feel the 'spirit faints' (e.g., a relationship, a choice)
Pray for God's Spirit to lead you to do His will in that area
Write down one step you can take this week to follow God's will

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy and for teaching us to do His will through His Spirit. Ask for strength to be led by Him.
tips: Thank God for being the only one who can teach us to do His will
Pray for the Spirit to lead you on level ground (a path of obedience without obstacles)
Ask God to help you avoid the enemy (sin) and live by His will

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 144:1-6 aloud, focusing on the contrast between God's strength (verses 1-2) and human frailty (verses 3-5), and the call to worship (verse 6).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'my rock' and 'my fortress' in verse 1
Pay attention to the dramatic language in verses 4-5: 'bow your heavens', 'flash forth the lightning'
The phrase 'what is man that you regard him?' (verse 3) is a rhetorical question that emphasizes human insignificance

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God and the psalmist) does WHAT (God trains for battle, God is the rock and fortress), WHERE (in the context of worship and battle), and WHY (to provide refuge and deliverance).
tips: Include the psalmist's plea for God to act (verses 4-5)
Note the contrast between God's eternal strength and human transience
The psalm ends with a declaration of blessing for those whose God is the Lord

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God as the rock and fortress (v.1), the rhetorical question about man (v.3), or the plea for rescue (v.4-5)?
tips: The phrase 'my rock' (v.1) is a strong declaration of God's reliability in times of conflict
The question 'what is man that you regard him?' (v.3) is a powerful reminder of human fragility
The command to 'bow your heavens' (v.4) shows the psalmist's hope for God's dramatic intervention

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about God through this passage?
tips: David emphasizes God's role as the ultimate protector in times of war and danger
The passage affirms that God's strength is sufficient for the psalmist's needs, even when human strength is gone
The theological significance is that God is the one who saves and delivers, not human effort

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'bow your heavens', the reference to 'foreigners' in verse 5, and the concept of God as the 'fortress'?
tips: 'Bow your heavens' (v.4) is a poetic expression meaning to cause the heavens to bend or lower, often used in the Bible for God's mighty acts
The term 'foreigners' (v.5) refers to nations or enemies that are not part of the covenant community
The concept of 'fortress' (v.1) is a place of safety, but here it is used metaphorically for God's protection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: God trains us for spiritual warfare. What situation requires you to trust God's protection this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel vulnerable to spiritual attacks
Pray for God to be your rock and fortress in that area
Practice being still and trusting God's provision for your needs

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being your rock and fortress. Ask for strength to trust Him in difficult times.
tips: Thank God for being your shield and deliverer
Pray for courage to face challenges with confidence in His strength
Ask God to help you sing the new song of redemption with others

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 145:1-41 aloud, paying attention to the acrostic structure (each verse begins with a different Hebrew letter) and the repetition of 'the Lord' and 'great'.
tips: Notice the acrostic pattern starts with 'I' (Hebrew aleph) in verse 1
Pay attention to the phrase 'Great is the Lord' (v.3) and the repetition of 'the Lord' throughout
The emotional tone shifts from majestic to compassionate

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praising, WHAT God is like, WHERE this praise occurs (in the context of worshiping Israel), and WHY they praise Him.
tips: Include the acrostic structure as a unique poetic device
Note that God is described as gracious, merciful, and a provider
The praise is for God's eternal kingdom and unsearchable greatness

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the acrostic structure (v.1-2), God's unsearchable greatness (v.3), or His provision for all (v.16-17)?
tips: The acrostic structure (Hebrew: 22 letters) shows the psalmist's intentional and complete praise
The phrase 'the Lord is gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love' (v.8) is a powerful description of God's character
The promise that 'the Lord upholds all who are falling and raises up all who are bowed down' (v.18) offers immediate comfort

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This psalm affirms that God's greatness is beyond human comprehension and that His kingdom is eternal
It calls Israel to recognize God as their gracious and merciful provider
The author intended to remind worshipers that God is the ultimate source of strength and provision

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The acrostic structure? The concept of 'unsearchable greatness'? How does God 'uphold' and 'raise up' in a fallen world?
tips: The acrostic structure is a Hebrew poetic device to ensure all letters of the alphabet are covered, but it's not literal in English
The term 'unsearchable' (Hebrew: 'mefarad') means beyond human understanding, emphasizing God's transcendence
God's upholding of the falling and raising of the bowed down (v.18) is a promise of active care in the midst of suffering

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's provision for all (v.16-17) this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel 'fallen' or 'bowed down' and pray for God's upholding
Surrender a specific need to God, trusting His provision as He does for all living things
Share a word of encouragement with someone who is struggling, reflecting God's grace

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His unsearchable greatness and eternal kingdom. Ask for His grace to be a provider in your life.
tips: Thank God for being the gracious and merciful Lord who upholds all who fall
Pray for courage to trust God's provision in difficult circumstances
Ask God to help you become a 'provider' for others as He does for all

chapters.chapterTitle: Put Not Your Trust in Princes

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 146:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'Praise the Lord' and the contrast between human rulers and God.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Praise the Lord' (vv. 1, 2, 10)
Pay attention to the phrase 'in a son of man' (v. 2) which refers to Christ
Note the contrast between temporary human rulers and eternal God (vv. 3-4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT God does, WHERE this praise occurs, and WHY the trust in princes is warned against.
tips: Include the warning against trusting in princes (v. 2)
Note the contrast between human rulers and God (vv. 3-4)
Mention God's active care for the vulnerable (vv. 5-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning against princes (v. 2), God's provision for the vulnerable (vv. 5-8), or the eternal reign (v. 9-10)?
tips: The phrase 'the Lord sets the prisoners free' (v. 6) shows God's active compassion
The description of God as the one who 'upholds the widow and the fatherless' (v. 7) is deeply relational
The declaration that God 'will reign forever' (v. 9) provides hope beyond human life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel about the danger of trusting in human leaders and the true help?
tips: This passage addresses the immediate context of worshiping Israel who might have been tempted to trust in human leaders (like kings)
It emphasizes that true help comes from God who is the creator and sustainer of all things (v. 4)
The focus is on God's eternal character and care for the marginalized, which contrasts with the temporary nature of human rulers

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'son of man', the meaning of 'princes', or the contrast between human and divine?
tips: 'Son of man' in Hebrew (benei adam) can refer to human rulers but also points to Christ (as in the New Testament) - this passage is part of the Old Testament context
In ancient Israel, 'princes' could mean the king or powerful leaders, but God is saying they are not reliable
The phrase 'when his breath departs' (v. 4) is a poetic way to express that human rulers die and their plans are forgotten

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning against trusting in princes to your current situation? What specific action can you take to trust God instead?
tips: Consider an area where you might be relying on human systems or leaders for security
Think about the vulnerable in your life (widows, orphans) and how God's care for them might inspire you to act
Practice shifting your trust from temporary human solutions to God's eternal provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His care of the vulnerable and ask for courage to trust Him instead of human leaders.
tips: Thank God for freeing prisoners and opening eyes (v. 6)
Ask for strength to be a helper to the widow and fatherless (v. 7)
Pray for the courage to trust God's eternal reign rather than the temporary promises of princes

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 148:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'Praise the Lord' and the progression from heavens to earth.
tips: Notice the phrase 'for He commanded and they were created' (v.6) which emphasizes God's sovereign authority
Pay attention to the inclusive language: 'all His angels, all His hosts, sun, moon, stars, waters above the heavens'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (all creation) does WHAT (praises the Lord), WHERE (from the heavens to the earth), and WHY (because He is the creator and sustainer).
tips: Include the range of creation: from angels and hosts to sea creatures, mountains, trees, and all peoples
Note the key phrase: 'for He commanded and they were created' (v.6) which shows God's role as the creator

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the cosmic scope (v.1-2), the inclusion of all creation (v.3-4), or the declaration of God's uniqueness (v.13).
tips: The phrase 'for He commanded and they were created' (v.6) is a powerful statement of God's authority in creation
The declaration 'His name alone is exalted' (v.13) emphasizes God's uniqueness and worthiness of praise

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: This psalm calls Israel to recognize God as the sovereign Creator who is worthy of all praise
It emphasizes that God's authority extends over all creation and that the entire universe is part of His design

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The scope of creation, the meaning of 'all hosts', or the theological implications of universal praise?
tips: 'All hosts' (v.2) refers to the host of heaven (angels) but in this context, it is used to include all created beings
The phrase 'for He commanded and they were created' (v.6) uses the Hebrew verb that implies divine authority and the act of creation, not a natural process

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be part of the universal praise community this week? Reflect on the theme of 'all creation praising' and how it applies to your life.
tips: Practice gratitude for the gift of creation (e.g., the sun, the trees, the animals) and share this with someone
Consider how you can be a 'praise' in your community by living in a way that reflects God's love

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is the creator and that all creation is called to praise Him. Ask for the courage to participate in this universal praise.
tips: Thank God for the beauty of creation and His sovereignty
Pray for the ability to see God's hand in the world and to share in the praise

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Psalms 149:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'Praise the Lord!' and the contrast between dancing and the sword.
tips: Notice the threefold repetition of 'Praise the Lord' in verses 1, 2, and 3 (v.1: 'Praise the Lord', v.2: 'Praise the Lord', v.3: 'Praise the Lord')
Pay attention to the contrast between the joy of dancing (tambourine, lyre) and the readiness for judgment (two-edged swords)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is praised, WHAT they do, WHERE this praise occurs, and WHY it is done (the reason).
tips: Include the godly (Israel) as the ones who praise
Note the actions: dancing, singing, and wielding two-edged swords for vengeance
The reason: because the Lord takes pleasure in His people and will deliver victory

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the dancing and singing (v.1-3), the Lord's pleasure in His people (v.4), or the two-edged swords (v.5-6)?
tips: The call to 'let the godly exult in glory' (v.5) shows the joy of being part of God's kingdom
The image of 'two-edged swords in their hands' (v.6) symbolizes the power of God's word to judge evil
The promise of 'binding the kings of nations with chains' (v.6) is a powerful sign of God's ultimate victory

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was David and others trying to communicate to worshiping Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage calls Israel to praise the Lord with joy and active participation in His victory
It emphasizes that the Lord delights in His people and will use them as instruments of judgment against enemies
This passage also points to the future where the saints will be victorious and the nations will be subdued

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The two-edged swords? The vengeance on nations? The Lord's pleasure in His people?
tips: The 'two-edged swords' (v.6) is a metaphor for the Word of God that can both defend and judge
The 'execute vengeance on the nations' (v.6) is a call for the saints to be active in God's justice, not to take vengeance on their own
The phrase 'the Lord takes pleasure in His people' (v.4) might seem odd because it's about the Lord's delight, but it emphasizes His love and care for the humble

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to praise with dancing and singing to your life this week?
tips: Find a time to dance and sing praise to God in your home or in a group
Remember that God uses you as a weapon of His word (like the two-edged sword) to bring justice in your sphere of influence
Pray that God will help you to be joyful in His provision and to be ready for His victory

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His victory and ask for the strength to praise Him with joy and to be instruments of His justice.
tips: Thank God for His pleasure in His people and for His victory over enemies
Ask for courage to be joyful in His presence and to be ready to wield the sword of His word
Pray for the church to be a community of praise and victory
